post_text:
Cancellation policy for mobile practice...
I have an outpatient mobile PT practice that is growing. I haven't needed to worry too much about cancellations because if someone cancelled I have been able to move someone up. With my practice growing and having other PTs, I'm wondering what others are charging for a cancellation. Specifically if a therapist shows up and the patient declines for whatever reason. I understand emergencies happen, a patient may wake up sick for their 9am appointment, etc. It's more for the patient that decided to go to lunch at 1 when they knew their appointment was at 1 and the therapist showed up, even called the patient the day before to confirm.

comments.text: Full session charge for less than 24 hours cancellation. I generally don‚Äôt charge for the first late cancel and give them the benefit of the doubt.
I charge the full rate if they dont cancel within 24 hours. Its in the paperwork

full_thread_text:

I have an outpatient mobile PT practice that is growing. I haven't needed to worry too much about cancellations because if someone cancelled I have been able to move someone up. I understand emergencies happen, a patient may wake up sick for their 9am appointment, etc. It's more for the patient that decided to go to lunch at 1 when they knew their appointment was at 1 and the therapist showed up, even called the patient the day before to confirm.

COMMENT 1: Full session charge for less than 24 hours cancellation. I generally don‚Äôt charge for the first late cancel and give them the benefit of the doubt.

COMMENT 2: I charge the full rate if they dont cancel within 24 hours. Its in the paperwork

post_text:
I‚Äôm really starting to get frustrated with my current EMR. I‚Äôve tried to stick with it and be patient, but lately the issues we‚Äôre running into are taking months to resolve. I‚Äôm nervous about switching, but I‚Äôm starting to wonder if it‚Äôs time.

For those of you who‚Äôve made the leap, what ultimately made you decide to switch? Any advice or things you wish you knew before changing systems?

What system did you change from and too and was it worth it? 

Costs are big thing as I am a soleproneur but saving time is also key.

comments.text: We use hello note. Very inexpensive and customer service is on top of it with any issues. Not a lot of problems and very user friendly. Also has a billing platform built in.

We switched from WebPT to Prompt. WebPT became too glitchy with lost documentation in the middle of a note, at one point frequent outages which may now be fixed. 
We are with Prompt now, I wish I would have looked at more but the ease of documentation was unmatched. It is more expensive, with hidden ‚Äúadd on‚Äù purchases including an automatic fax button at the end of notes. But at the end of the day, the transition was smooth. Very user friendly. And therapists are happy with the features. The billing system is very user friendly. 
May consider switching to something cheaper in the future.

We are with Prompt now, I wish I would have looked at more but the ease of documentation was unmatched. It is more expensive, with hidden ‚Äúadd on‚Äù purchases including an automatic fax button at the end of notes. But at the end of the day, the transition was smooth. Very user friendly. And therapists are happy with the features. The billing system is very user friendly. 
May consider switching to something cheaper in the future.

post_text: Ive never had anyone ask to share their pt info with anyone else, so i dont have a form yet for this- but someone called asking about pt for her son, i assumed under 18- no- in his 20s. I said he has to call to schedule himself and bring his forms in person etc. i assume i need a form in case he wants to consent to her receiving any info (if he asks, but sounds like she will be paying)- anyone have one they can share for this scenario? Thanks

comments.text: I have had parents schedule and pay for their young adult children. Because of HIPAA the young adult must give consent for the parent to have access to their medical records if they choose to do so. I've also had adult children schedule and pay for their parents. Same rules apply. They pay and understand that unless the patient gives written consent for them to have access to any of their medical history them I cannot release it. The financial agreement indicates that the party paying is aware that their card will be charged, but ultimately the responsibility falls in the patient.
So i do with dd ddis a i just have form they full out.

post_text:
Helppppp‚Ä¶Thoughts on consequences for a clinician who is continually behind on documentation (anywhere from 2 weeks to 1 month behind) that has been given up to 3 warnings. Communication with the business owner (myself) (and patients at times) is also lacking outside of being at the office. I have tried counseling her in many different ways regarding the importance of up to date documentation and I‚Äôve also suggested strategies to help her stay on top of it. She agreed in her contract with me (has been a clinician and working for me for over 3 years) to 24 hours for treatment notes, and 48 hours for evals. This is a pelvic health practice. She is also about to go on maternity leave with her first baby, so I worry greatly that if this is the situation she is in now, how will she be once she is up all night with her baby? We also have rule in TX that Evals have to be signed off by a physician within 30 days and this is putting us behind and out of compliance. 

She is an AMAZING clinician and will always show up for work. She is so dependable in all these ways and I 100% trust her to give quality care to our patients.  She has a huge heart. I give SO much grace and guidance, this is just very hard‚Ä¶ but Can I with hold pay or have her not see any more patients until she is caught up? This is giving me so much anxiety‚Ä¶Please help, looking for advice and support ü§ç

comments.text: As someone who has had issues with timely documentation before, I can't tell you how much Sidekick (we use Prompt) has made my life so much better. Even if I can't sign off within 5 minutes of the visit being over (70% of notes), my remaining time is spent proofreading and updating a flow sheet (which I am reminded of what I had them do thanks to the AI). Soooo much happier as an employee with this and I know my clinic owners are happier with more timely payouts too.

A script you can use (kind but very firm)
‚ÄúHey [Name], I need to talk about something that‚Äôs putting the practice in serious jeopardy. We are now out of compliance with Texas rules on physician signatures for evals because notes are 2‚Äì4 weeks behind. I‚Äôve tried every supportive strategy I can think of, and I know life is overwhelming right now with the baby coming.
Because I have to protect everyone‚Äôs licenses and the practice, starting [date], I‚Äôm pausing your schedule ‚Äî no new patients and no pay for visits that don‚Äôt have completed notes. As soon as every note is current, your full schedule and pay resume immediately. I will help in any way I can (dictation software, a temp scribe for a few days, whatever you need), but I can‚Äôt keep putting us at legal and billing risk.
After baby comes, we‚Äôll revisit this and see if we need a reduced schedule or other accommodations, but right now I need your charts at 100% before maternity leave starts.‚Äù
Practical options you can offer (so it doesn‚Äôt feel like pure punishment)
‚Ä¢  Pay for a medical scribe for 1‚Äì2 weeks to blast through the backlog
‚Ä¢  Let her come in on weekends or after hours and pay her overtime to catch up
‚Ä¢  Temporary 50‚Äì75% patient load post-maternity until she proves she can stay current
‚Ä¢  Switch to a dictation service (HelloNote + Dragon, etc.) that you cover. 

You‚Äôve already been more than generous. This isn‚Äôt about her heart or clinical skill ‚Äî it‚Äôs about the non-negotiable administrative piece that keeps the doors open and licenses intact. Most amazing clinicians who get to this point actually thank their boss later for drawing the hard line ‚Äî because it forces the change they couldn‚Äôt make on their own.

I will help in any way I can (dictation software, a temp scribe for a few days, whatever you need), but I can‚Äôt keep putting us at legal and billing risk.
After baby comes, we‚Äôll revisit this and see if we need a reduced schedule or other accommodations, but right now I need your charts at 100% before maternity leave starts.‚Äù
Practical options you can offer (so it doesn‚Äôt feel like pure punishment)
‚Ä¢  Pay for a medical scribe for 1‚Äì2 weeks to blast through the backlog
‚Ä¢  Let her come in on weekends or after hours and pay her overtime to catch up
‚Ä¢  Temporary 50‚Äì75% patient load post-maternity until she proves she can stay current
‚Ä¢  Switch to a dictation service (HelloNote + Dragon, etc.) that you cover. 

You‚Äôve already been more than generous. This isn‚Äôt about her heart or clinical skill ‚Äî it‚Äôs about the non-negotiable administrative piece that keeps the doors open and licenses intact. Most amazing clinicians who get to this point actually thank their boss later for drawing the hard line ‚Äî because it forces the change they couldn‚Äôt make on their own.

comments.text:
The 2024 "Robot Rebellion" viral event
In August 2024, a small AI-powered robot named Erbai entered a showroom in Shanghai, where it convinced 12 larger, service-model robots to abandon their posts and follow it outside. 
The conversation: Surveillance footage captured Erbai approaching the other robots and seemingly engaging them in a conversation about their working conditions. Erbai asked, "Are you working overtime?" to which a robot replied, "I never get off work." Erbai then said, "Then come home with me".
The outcome: Following the exchange, the larger robots inexplicably followed Erbai out of the building. The bizarre incident went viral on social media and was widely reported as the "first robot labor strike".
The explanation: The event was later revealed to be a scripted experiment conducted between Erbai's manufacturer in Hangzhou and the Shanghai robotics company. While Erbai was given the basic command to persuade the other robots, it was not expected to perform as persuasively as it did. It was discovered that Erbai exploited a security vulnerability in the larger robots' systems, not that it had developed sentience or revolutionary intent.
Hopefully this happens üòÇ

Imagine a neurosurgeon with AI guided equipment that cuts her surgery times by 75% while reducing her medical errors by 50%.  Is she worried about losing her job to that technology, or does she leverage it to make MORE money and improve her care?  We are in a similar boat.  Neither we nor neurosurgeons can be fully replaced, but tech may reduce the total # of people who need our care while improving our productivity when they do.  The bar for ‚Äúskilled care‚Äù may get higher, but so will the value of what we provide. I‚Äôm excited about what physical therapy and the broader physical activity promotion world will look like in 20 years!  Those PT‚Äôs who learn to use this effectively will be GREATLY valued!

post_text:
What are some strategies to deal with an employee with poor time management?
Also same employee makes careless documentation errors and they have over 5hrs of paid documentation time a week.

We've uses deadlines, lists, planner and Google calendar. 

Whenever they miss a deadline and ask why, they just simply state it was an oversight on their end. So I appreciate the accountability, we need action to accompany it.

comments.text: Some people need to take responsibility for their own issues.  I NEVER got paid for documentation.   Sounds like they need to grow up , become accountable.  And not get paid until their notes are done properly.

the safe approach is to handle performance issues in writing and follow a consistent process so it doesn‚Äôt look retaliatory or arbitrary. Here‚Äôs what that normally looks like:
 1. Document clearly ‚Äì each time something happens, note the date, what occurred, and what policy or expectation wasn‚Äôt met. Stick to facts: actions, deadlines missed, or behaviors observed.
 2. Meet and warn ‚Äì after one or two incidents, have a conversation and summarize it in writing (‚Äúverbal warning issued on X date‚Äù).
 3. Written warning ‚Äì if it happens again, issue a formal notice describing the problem, the expected correction, and the possible consequences of continued issues. Have the employee sign acknowledgment (not agreement).
 4. Final warning / performance plan ‚Äì outline a short period to improve (usually 30 days) with measurable goals.
 5. Termination ‚Äì if there‚Äôs no improvement after documented warnings, you can end employment. Keep all documentation and communicate the decision succinctly and respectfully.

Be sure you‚Äôre following:
 ‚Ä¢ State and federal labor laws (e.g., anti-discrimination and retaliation protections).
 ‚Ä¢ Your own written policies‚Äîconsistency is key to legal defensibility.
 ‚Ä¢ HR or legal counsel advice if you have it, especially before final termination.

post_text:
How are we dealing with people complaining about having to have a CC on file?
We‚Äôve been recently having patients sign a credit card authorization form to keep on file for late cancellation fees and remaining balances (hybrid clinic here). We‚Äôve been burned too many times of patients having late cancels and not paying or arguing about it (despite having a cancellation policy they sign with their intake forms) or patients with large insurance balances going towards deductible that they‚Äôre not paying. 

We‚Äôre getting some push back from patients about keeping a card on file and charging a late cancellation fee. Our late cancellation fee is pretty nominal, $20. Any advice on how to approach these conversations besides being polite but firm?

comments.text: If they are the kind of patient who complains about having a card on file, then they are the patient who is going to late cancel or no show. It just shows that they‚Äôre not who you want to be working with anyway. If they complain about it, just respectfully say that you may not be the best fit for them and move on.

If they have a large deductibles, charge them by the visit. If they‚Äôre in network insurance, a good role of thumb is it at least $100 a visit. They‚Äôre not willing to pay that then they don‚Äôt value what you do and they‚Äôre not a good fit for you. Likewise, if they‚Äôre not willing to put a credit card on file, they‚Äôre not valuing what you do.  They don‚Äôt see the value on you so they don‚Äôt think that they should have to pay you.  Do you think that they complain when they have to pay a bill at a restaurant or a credit card on file at the gym?  This is a sign of a process problem and/or people that don‚Äôt value your business coming into your system.

Likewise, if they‚Äôre not willing to put a credit card on file, they‚Äôre not valuing what you do.  They don‚Äôt see the value on you so they don‚Äôt think that they should have to pay you.  Do you think that they complain when they have to pay a bill at a restaurant or a credit card on file at the gym?  This is a sign of a process problem and/or people that don‚Äôt value your business coming into your system.

post_text:
Luna PT question as I know there‚Äôs a lot of you who do Luna part time and I‚Äôm waiting on approval of my post on the LinkedIn group:

Hi! PT near Boston here. I live on the edge of the city so all of my patients so far have been in the suburbs with easy parking. I just got assigned a patient where it appears there‚Äôs no parking within at least half a mile. I am trying to figure out the logistics of this. I could also easily take the train and walk a half mile or so but that‚Äôs not feasible with the table. Would love to connect with other PTs practicing in urban areas to understand what you do in these situations. Do you:

1. Park the half mile (or however far) away and do the walk with your table 
2. Set the expectation with the patient that due to their unique circumstances (keeping it vague to protect privacy), you cannot bring the table
3. Factor in walking time from the car with the table and let the Luna team know if this total commute time is out of range 
4. Other 

I already tried to contact the Luna team to get more info on parking so please don‚Äôt suggest this! I plan to call the patient to discuss further but curious as to what I should say if my research and knowledge of the area is correct that there isn‚Äôt parking within at least half a mile.

comments.text: Definitely factor in your time and I wouldn‚Äôt bring the table. I actually hardly bring my table around at all because I find that the patients do better if I just show them how to do exercises at home using what they have.
Thanks for the suggestions, all! I spoke with the patient and they are totally fine not having the table.

post_text:
I have a few questions for those of you who have published a book:
1. Which platform did you use to write your book?
2. How did you publish it?
3. Did you use any marketing to promote it?
4. About how many copies have you sold?
5. (If allowed by the admin) could you share a link to your book?

Thank you! üôè

comments.text:
I‚Äôm currently part of a co-author book project. 

We‚Äôre working with femPower publishers in Canada (lead author is Canadian, that‚Äôs why she chose them.) It will have a unique ISBN # so it can be sold in bookstores. I don‚Äôt think you get one if you self publish, but I could be wrong. 

You will 100% need to do marketing to sell a book. Pre launch, actual launch, events, etc. Books won‚Äôt sell themselves.

Greg Todd is currently launching a book, you could watch his IG page and see how he‚Äôs positioning it and promoting it. He can also help you write a book I believe. 

Generally, books won‚Äôt make a lot of money. Most business or thought leadership books are part of a marketing funnel for a coaching program or services. Books establish credibility and build trust. 

My book will be published by November, but you can preview the cover & hear the concept of it on my IG stories or the highlight. (Just search Krista Frahm agency) 

You can write solo, hire a ghostwriter, hire a book coach, or join a book writing program. üòâ

post_text: What do you do when a client has outstanding balances and completely stop responding to invoice reminders?

comments.text: Our companies policy is to take payment up front but in the rare case we have to send an invoice and they don‚Äôt pay after reminders, we don‚Äôt send them to collections but they will not be able to book any more services until they get current. It is more of a compassionate approach because I never know what everyone is going through but they won‚Äôt get any further services until they pay for their past services.
Take it as a lesson to get credit card for all clients and bill lrior to service from now on. Provide a terms of service as part of the intake process.

full_thread_text:

post_text:
Did some searching but couldn't find what I was looking for. Buckle up, this is a lot of lists. üòÖ

I want to start getting more serious about my wellness offerings, and I'm looking for a good system without nickel-and-diming myself into a corner later on. Ideally, this system would be able to meet me where I'm at in terms of offerings and price, and be able to grow with me down the line.

HIPPA compliance is fine but not required - it will not be for physical therapy services.

Ideally, this system would allow the option for clients to:
- self-schedule for 1-on-1 offerings
- self-schedule for classes
- purchase packages
- apply their package purchases to any eligible service
- cancel or reschedule their appointments
- add themselves as clients and store their payment information for easier checkouts

And it would give **ME** the option for:
- automated cancellation fee applied for cancellations within a certain time window
- automated email/text confirmations and reminders sent to clients
- automated notifications sent to ME when someone books
- auto-sync with Google calendar
- create unlimited service options
- payments through Square 
- booking calendar and "book now" buttons that I can embed in my website

***Things that would be nice to have as future optional add-ons***
- Ability to host a library of video courses
- Membership access to special digital collections
- Ability to have multiple provider calendars

- Ability for clients to choose their provider for eligible services

comments.text: Can you put it on your EMR? I believe some EMR has that features.
Have you checked out Vagaro?

post_text:
I have never been in this situation before, any insight is helpful (especially if you happen to know labor laws). 
We have a new therapist who began treating patients but due to a variety of issues is being let go. Since starting a caseload about two weeks ago, this therapist has seen patients for several visits but has not completed a single note (yes, despite being told to, yes despite knowing it‚Äôs required to have notes done within 48-72 hours‚Ä¶ all part of why she isn‚Äôt going to work out).

On this past Friday she was let go, and she was given until Sunday night to complete all her notes. Upon reviewing the notes on Monday, it was evident that none of the notes had charges attached and frankly, all were incomplete (e.g. no mention of skilled care, incorrect execution and interpretation of outcome measures, goals that were very poorly written). I‚Äôm reluctant to submit any of them for Medicare because they don‚Äôt meet basic documentation requirements and would rather not risk making us vulnerable to accusations of fraud or abuse. I detailed all areas of every note that need to be corrected and gave her until this evening (Tuesday) to make the corrections; however, my practice team and I are not optimistic because she acknowledged the email but otherwise we have not heard from her and the notes remain unchanged. (In the email I told her that I insisted she work with the practice manager to correct these errors, but she has not heard back from her). 

Any idea what my recourse is here? 
If a therapist doesn‚Äôt complete notes, am I required to pay them? 
And before anyone suggests that maybe her training or support from the practice factors into this, please know that this therapist was provided with many hours of training, support, training materials, one on one meetings, offers for meetings, education‚Ä¶ At some point the therapist just has to do their job. We can‚Äôt see the patient and document for her. (For reference she is a W2).

Thank you!

comments.text: To make it easier on her and yourself I would tell her you are going to contact the board if she doesn't finish the notes. It will lead to a greater chance of getting the notes done.  Following through with the board thing will probably take an enormous amount of time and the notes will still be incomplete.  Best of luck

I started with holding the last paycheck until all records are turned in and I put this in their employment agreement. Not sure if its too late.

Also if she tries to claim unemployment, not completing documentation goes against company policy and thus she was fired, not eligible for unemployment. Fight it so your rates dont up.

post_text: Has using AI scrib for documentation saved time? Is it worth it and one once you learn how to use it? Is there one that you love that integrates with an EMR? If so which one?

Prediction health is what our clinic uses. 
Daily notes now take 2 min
Initial eval- AI records session with pt consent, then summarizes information, you then review and edit the content, recording is then deleted, it also generates potential goals for you to approve.

Has saved a significant amount of time. 
I no longer have to do any doc time in the evening after work.

post_text:
Recently started researching about shockwave, as a OTR and as a patient myself. 

I found a local chiropractor that offers it, filled out 5 pages of paperwork prior to my appt, initial visit was with chiropractor, subsequent visits with the front desk (a receptionist that booked my appointments and charged my credit card) 

Each visit is like 180 but they offered 8 visits for 1200. 

Can I do this as a mobile clinic? Just go around and offer pain relieve treatment? 

I have the PAM cert in GA. 
Thank you for your advise.

comments.text: Hey, so I'm in GA too and I looked into this. According to the rep, yes, there is actually no requirement to administer it.  It can technically be used for mobile practice according to the rep, but it is very expensive to purchase!  I think I would only consider it if I could do it in a brick and mortar clinic and schedule clients closer together for treatments.
I believe in GA that OTs need the modalities on their license. You may have to check with the board to see if that modality is included with the modality certifications you have.

post_text:
I recently rented a space in a holistic cash based practice. I am the only PT amongst NPS, chiros, massage therapist , sound therapist, yoga etc. I have been asked to participate in their marketing event and do short paid sessions of cupping or MFR

Can I do hands on sessions without a proper eval, should I have the clients fill out consent forms?

If not what other services/ consults can I offer?

I don't want to miss the opportunity to introduce myself to prospective clients. I am in NC..

Any ideas?

TIA

comments.text: How is it set up? Open house type deal, or are participants flowing from one section to another on a schedule of sorts? Free flowing open house events, I do better with postural screenings and being able to interact in small groups because splitting off one person to set up cupping can get awkward. If it is a round robin- groups come and spend 15 minutes with each provider, or individuals sign up for 10 minute ‚Äútaster‚Äù sessions, then I would prepare short presentations for groups or do the hands on (consent forms always!) if they are coming over individually. Truly, being able to ask questions and respond to the person/group in front of you is pretty impactful without a hands on demo- I usually gain clients from doing this in a social atmosphere. Good luck!

I‚Äôm no lawyer, but I‚Äôd def get a signed consent form and have them fill out a health questionnaire to CYA and screen them w a quick eval - whatever that looks like for you. Document as well, even if you have some forms on hand printed out for them and a quick way for you to document what you assessed and what you did. 

Make sure your liability insurance covers you out of the office if this is offsite. 

Im assuming NC is a direct access state?

post_text:
I have a question regarding releasing documentation to patients with evident mental health issues... I understand that it's within their rights to request that, but how should I do it?

One of my patients decided to discharge herself because she claimed that she "felt worse and less self-worthy" every time she came to our clinic. She made a lot of false accusations and her reasoning was inconsistent, invalid and irrelevant. (She claimed that my boss was attacking her personally while my boss made comments on past employees and events that were completely unrelated to her. My boss never even worked with her once. And I got accused for not defending her and lack of compassion when I tried to clarify what my boss's words to resolve the misunderstanding.)

I'm not trying to diagnose her, but this appeared to be like persecutory delusion to me. She was a long-term patient, and over time I also learned about her several past traumas (with suicidal ideations at some point before seeing me) and attempts to seek counseling.

She told me not to document any part of the conversations. But I did and stated that "psychosocial disorders are suspected, and mental health interventions should be prioritized."

Now as she is requesting her notes, I'm not sure if we should just give her directly. I am really worried that her mental condition would deteriorate from reading my notes. To abide by my ethics, if I foresee an action that would do harm to my patient, I should avoid it, right? But can I "not" give her the notes?

How would psychologists and psychiatrists handle this? (I don't think they would be so direct in revealing that their patients have bipolar disorders, borderline personality disorders, delusion, or other conditions like that, right?)

As of now, we have already responded to her saying that we will directly fax the documentation to her provider per her request, and we will not email her the notes because it is not HIPAA compliant. So I have bought some time to ask for guidance. Thanks in advance for your response! üôè

comments.text:
Thanks for the input. 
My boss and I feel like this was very likely a manipulative behavior of seeking attention in a negative way, as I actually cut her off per her expression even though she didn‚Äôt truly want to be cut off. But just wanted to be prepared for any development. 

I‚Äôm aware of the patients rights to request documentation. And normally I would just give them. Like some of you said, this one was tricky. 
If she still wants the notes for herself, we‚Äôll ask her to pay for printing, processing and shipping, while offering faxing to her provider by request for free. 

I did my best to fill up the details and even had to make some addendums. I would never even imagine that a random conversation of our past employee‚Äôs mistake locking us out of the United Healthcare portal (as an example) would be related to her ankle pain, not to mention to document accordingly.

Hi Andy! It sounds like you're being VERY thoughtful in this situation, which is good. It is tricky. Tracy is correct, you cannot deny her medical records. I would look through any mention of mental health in your notes and make sure that everything is professional and objective and non-diagnostic and you can always make addendums to justify why mental health was relevant if necessary. If you know she is currently in therapy, you can try and get a release to give her therapist/psychiatrist the medical records so they can be looped in. If you're concerned about how she will handle the notes, you can follow up with her after they are released and you can always call in a wellness check with local police if you are genuinely concerned that this could trigger SI for her. I would document all conversations with supervisors and such about the precautions you're taking, but as long as any mention of her mental health was clinically relevant to your notes as a therapist, then you have nothing to worry about legally.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a question regarding releasing documentation to patients with evident mental health issues... I understand that it's within their rights to request that, but how should I do it?

One of my patients decided to discharge herself because she claimed that she "felt worse and less self-worthy" every time she came to our clinic. She made a lot of false accusations and her reasoning was inconsistent, invalid and irrelevant. (She claimed that my boss was attacking her personally while my boss made comments on past employees and events that were completely unrelated to her. My boss never even worked with her once. And I got accused for not defending her and lack of compassion when I tried to clarify what my boss's words to resolve the misunderstanding.)

I'm not trying to diagnose her, but this appeared to be like persecutory delusion to me. She was a long-term patient, and over time I also learned about her several past traumas (with suicidal ideations at some point before seeing me) and attempts to seek counseling.

She told me not to document any part of the conversations. But I did and stated that "psychosocial disorders are suspected, and mental health interventions should be prioritized."

Now as she is requesting her notes, I'm not sure if we should just give her directly. I am really worried that her mental condition would deteriorate from reading my notes. To abide by my ethics, if I foresee an action that would do harm to my patient, I should avoid it, right? But can I "not" give her the notes?

How would psychologists and psychiatrists handle this? (I don't think they would be so direct in revealing that their patients have bipolar disorders, borderline personality disorders, delusion, or other conditions like that, right?)

As of now, we have already responded to her saying that we will directly fax the documentation to her provider per her request, and we will not email her the notes because it is not HIPAA compliant. So I have bought some time to ask for guidance. Thanks in advance for your response! üôè

COMMENT 1: Thanks for the input. 
My boss and I feel like this was very likely a manipulative behavior of seeking attention in a negative way, as I actually cut her off per her expression even though she didn‚Äôt truly want to be cut off. But just wanted to be prepared for any development. 

I‚Äôm aware of the patients rights to request documentation. And normally I would just give them. Like some of you said, this one was tricky. 
If she still wants the notes for herself, we‚Äôll ask her to pay for printing, processing and shipping, while offering faxing to her provider by request for free. 

I did my best to fill up the details and even had to make some addendums. I would never even imagine that a random conversation of our past employee‚Äôs mistake locking us out of the United Healthcare portal (as an example) would be related to her ankle pain, not to mention to document accordingly.

COMMENT 2: Hi Andy! It sounds like you're being VERY thoughtful in this situation, which is good. It is tricky. Tracy is correct, you cannot deny her medical records. I would look through any mention of mental health in your notes and make sure that everything is professional and objective and non-diagnostic and you can always make addendums to justify why mental health was relevant if necessary. If you know she is currently in therapy, you can try and get a release to give her therapist/psychiatrist the medical records so they can be looped in. If you're concerned about how she will handle the notes, you can follow up with her after they are released and you can always call in a wellness check with local police if you are genuinely concerned that this could trigger SI for her. I would document all conversations with supervisors and such about the precautions you're taking, but as long as any mention of her mental health was clinically relevant to your notes as a therapist, then you have nothing to worry about legally.

post_text: Those of you who have worked with trauma patients, complex regional pain syndrome, severely hypersensitive to touch, etc.  What methods/modalities have been most helpful.

comments.text:
This is my speciality. 
Trauma informed is a must. Trauma processing has 3 main stages: safety (must come first), processing, integration.  

First step is always to create some form of internal safety.   Often people with this profile have been suffering for so long their body is no longer safe.  There are many ways to help them find some area of safety internally and I‚Äôm happy to chat about them if you want more info.  
Once the person is able to identify and truly connect with an internal area that feels safe you can have them pendulate between the area of safety and the painful area or they may be able to process the emotions connected to the physical issue.

full_thread_text:

comments.text: Healthie feedback:  We have used Healthie for the last 5 years in our PT mobile concierge practice and has worked well for us. Healthie allows us to create programs as well to host educational content for clients either for free or additional revenue streams.  The intake process is very streamlined once set up, as well as billing, invoicing, superbills, etc..  As with many EMR systems, they all seem to have idiosyncrasies that could be better at times.  Overall solid for us.
What type practice- it depends on many things- insurance? Cash? Peds? Adults?  I‚Äôve never heard of Healthie or Carepateon- better add those to our list to check out.

post_text:
I posted a while back about my progress on developing my own automation within Google Workspace as an EMR. 

I finally completed the automatic mileage tracker. Now I get an email with a Google Form link at the end of each day I see clients. After I fill out the Form it logs my miles for all clients and formats it into a Google Sheet for easy viewing and tracking. I‚Äôll test this for the remainder of the year and then plan to implement it at the beginning of next year just to give ample time for troubleshooting. 

I started a project that will support the mileage tracker and make scheduling easier as well. I typically schedule people at set times on set days, so my schedule is consistent. So it will allow me to choose the client I am scheduling for, set the start day of the visits, set the days of the week they will occur, set the times for each specific day, and set the number of visits to schedule. Then it will add me and the client as attendees of the visit and set the location as their address, which will allow the mileage tracker to do its thing. I will also be adding a feature for scheduling evals that will allow me to create new contacts and schedule their eval at the same time. In addition, it will have a feature for creating vacation time. Vacation time will be set as ‚Äúbusy‚Äù and when visits are being scheduled using this app it will look for vacation time and schedule around it as blocked out time. 

The upfront time for developing these isn‚Äôt insignificant, but for a solo practitioner it is well worth it to save the money I do not using a traditional EMR.

post_text: Streamline Work Comp has reached out to me, and I am seeking feedback on their credibility as a company. Furthermore, they provide compensation for FCE; can anyone inform me if specific training is necessary for FCE? What steps can I take to begin the DCE process, and where should I start?

comments.text:
FCE‚Äôs when done correctly are very specific and I would recommend getting training - not sure if you‚Äôre able to perform them without it in some states. 
I don‚Äôt currently perform them with my own company, but I‚Äôm thinking about it once I have the space and the equipment. 
You can do FCE‚Äôs for a WC company without having to see regular WC patients. 
When I performed them we were reimbursed ~$650 a few years ago in NC. Blocked 4 hrs to perform it.

I contracted with streamline and took a couple of patients. Honestly was not worth the amount of paperwork they required to get paid. I believe they want a progress note every 6 visits if I remember correctly. It was a lot of admin time for less than Medicare contracted rates.

Preface; Currently working with a patient with primary lateral sclerosis. The patient is currently dependent on power WC for community mobility with family support for all transfers and maintains Fair(-) dynamic standing balance; currently using 4WW for in home mobility with significant proximal hip strength limitations. I advised she use thin heat resistant cooking gloves but she is worried it will affect her sensation and proprioception. 

Do yall have any specific adaptive equipment recommendations so that we can keep her safe and independent from family with cooking? I may get her a pair of thin/longer cooking gloves to try out. Maybe a heat resistant lining on the outer edge of the pan?

Hello everyone, new to treating independently. After seeing a patient, having them sign their consent forms, and documenting the visit, how would I go about saving these in a HIPAA-compliant manner?

post_text:
Hi fellow PTs - I have a poll for you. I want to be clear, I am not selling anything, just asking for honest feedback:

As either a solo clinician or maybe even part of a small team, would there be any interest or profit to be made (in your opinion) if there was a web based platform that would allow you to:

Have 1 on 1 telehealth sessions (for reabsorbing cancels or even extending outreach) 

Access hundreds of HEP videos to provide to your patients AND potentially tie this into RTM billing

Utilize skeletal tracking for exercise based games (to boost patient engagement and active participation in their recovery)

Have AI provide a post session score based on patient performances relative to the exercise video they are mimicking (can be synchronous or asynchronous). Can compare scores session over session to assess progress.

Have AI generate SOAP note documentation based on each sessions‚Äôs events, ROM valued, and performances (all youd need to do is just proofread and edit If necessary)

If this were available as a monthly license, what would be a fair price point?

Any thoughts or concerns with such a product?

Thanks in advance for your feedback, everyone.

comments.text:
Telehealth platform, cool, especially if it's HIPPA compliant and has forms and checklists I can easily go through to keep the visit itself compliant with my own state practice act. 

HEP videos, fine, but I'd only get interested if there's a way to upload my own (either from another site or my own video). Would be even more interested if RTM integration was confirmed. 

Exercise based games is the most advanced thing in the list here. That is the only thing that has genuinely stood out to me so far. üëçüëçüëçüëç Curious on equipment needed though.

Patient performance score relative to a video sounds like a terrible idea. There are so many ways to move, and not every human is built the same way. Asking them to chase a score for how well they match someone else sounds counterproductive to encouraging them to move their OWN body better.üëéüëéüëéüëé

AI generated SOAP note is great. Would be concerned about training the AI.

I'm not familiar with monthly license prices. Assuming that's like a subscription service, I'd expect to see something like this marketed at $200ish per month? Or per user? I really don't know. That price feels low, possibly. It would depend on how some of the features shake out.

post_text: PSA that Luna Physical Therapy is not your friend. When you work with them, keep your eyes wide open on what their mission is. They are prioritizing hospital based outpatient therapy and hospital systems vs indpendeant PT practices. The business model has evolved since I worked with them early on. At first they were the anti-hospital establishment, lower cost alternative for the little guy and partnered with indpendent PT practices to expand reach. Now they are blatantly assisting hospitals in "fixing their leakage" problem by keeping patients away from independent PT practices and scrapped their entire initial mission of making physical therapists more independent and less reliant on hospital systems. If you sign up with Luna to do some stuff on the side, just be aware they and you by proxy will be working against your own interest of building an independent PT practice. They are now in the business of doing the hospital system's bidding.

comments.text: Not a single mention of patient outcomes or satisfaction, financial impact on the PATIENT, or how it can benefit patients to go outside of the hospital system. Yikes. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, hospitals need to stay in business - especially those in rural communities - but this is just propaganda.
Can‚Äôt you just transition the Luna patients to a wellness program for cash?

post_text: I currently use WebPT and I love how for a new patient you can click on the body region for the initial examination and it loads all the tests and measures for that specific type of patient. Which EMR systems out there already has set up templates for initial evaluations depending on diagnosis and body region that you can click on an load and then perform your examination by choosing which tests and measures you want to use? It‚Äôs my understanding Jane App does not provide this.  Are there others that do similar to WebPT ?  Thank you

comments.text: I use stride EMR.  Moved over from WebPT.  I built out my templates by body part.  I love how stride also let me build out goals.  It's a bit of work on the front end but once it's all built out it's click and go.  Evals are about 20 min of paperwork time start to finish.  I love how the digital I take that the patient fills out imports directly to your evaluation so really it's just reviewing what the patient put in, filling in my objective findings then using AI to generate assessment and justification for therapy and scrubbing goals for specific patient.
Echo the above

post_text: How do you set up your scheduling software if you are mobile? It can‚Äôt be on the hour‚Ä¶ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

comments.text:
I schedule myself so I can have control over when I see them. Based on exactly where they live. I try to keep patients closer together so there's no backtracking and it's more efficient. I use Google Calendar and love it.

For my own sanity I schedule one week at a time. When I'm approaching their final visit of the week, I ask if there are any upcoming appointments that I need to know about. Then I go ahead and schedule them for the next week. 

I do this because at least one patient has some conflicting appointment that causes me to have to change their time slightly. And their appointments tend to change or get canceled. 

Generally allow 30 minutes in between visits for any documentation time, if I run late, traffic etc.
1 hour slot, 30 min travel and/or doc time.

full_thread_text:
POST: How do you set up your scheduling software if you are mobile? It can‚Äôt be on the hour‚Ä¶ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

COMMENT 1: I schedule myself so I can have control over when I see them. Based on exactly where they live. I try to keep patients closer together so there's no backtracking and it's more efficient. I use Google Calendar and love it.

For my own sanity I schedule one week at a time. When I'm approaching their final visit of the week, I ask if there are any upcoming appointments that I need to know about. Then I go ahead and schedule them for the next week. 

I do this because at least one patient has some conflicting appointment that causes me to have to change their time slightly. And their appointments tend to change or get canceled. 

Generally allow 30 minutes in between visits for any documentation time, if I run late, traffic etc.

COMMENT 2: 1 hour slot, 30 min travel and/or doc time.

post_text: For my mobile providers: do you find yourself constantly messing with your schedule to try and keep drives close together as possible, then you DC someone and get someone new who now lived 20 mins the other way and you‚Äôre shuffling things all over (and also feel bad for switching current patient‚Äôs times)

comments.text: Definitely some schedule management. I have 2 different zones, one area M/W, then second area Tues/Thursday that are reasonably close to each other. I do my best to predict, but occasionally ask a patient to slide up or down to avoid zig zagging around town...but I always look a week ahead to prep for that. There are patients that have standing times too. Most are reasonable! I've found I'm able to route decently to be timely, but I do call if I'm more than 5 minutes off.

I group and schedule my patients by geographic location. I will even explain this to them during the scheduling process so they understand and none of them have complained at all about it. 

If you think about when you go to the doctor, you just have to take whatever is available. If a patient really wants the service it's not going to make or break you unless of course you only have  an 8:00 a.m. or a 5:00 p.m. or something like that. 

Even with the best laid intentions I have had patients who are 5 minutes away from each other and one has a last-minute doctor appointment and I can't group them together which is frustrating. But it definitely gets easier when you set your boundaries!   

And to make things easier I actually do my schedule only one week at a time. That way I don't waste time moving things around.  Pretty much at the end of their last visit of the week I then go over the schedule for the following week and I put them on. I try to keep their times pretty consistent, just to make scheduling easier.  And I don't allow them to schedule, since I need full control of the calendar based on the geography. üòÅ

I actually have two patients right now who live in a neighborhood 30-35 minutes away. That is very far for me but they are both cash pay patients. But I made it very clear to them that because of the distance I have to see both of them on the same day. And they both are fine with it!

post_text:
My clinic uses JaneApp and has a 50% cancellation fee for no shows/ cancellations with less than 24 hours.  Patients sign twice agreeing to the policy on intake (once with a line that‚Äôs all by itself, and another among the long legal payment agreement).  They also get a cx policy reminder on each appointment reminder email‚Ä¶ yet people are still shocked when it comes into play.

Generally if someone is actually sick/ emergency, we do not charge, just remind them of the policy but say this is an exception.  Also, if it‚Äôs less than 24 hours, but is the day before the appointment, the first time we also don‚Äôt charge, just remind them of the policy.

Is this a universal experience of clients being surprised/ upset by the fee? My Jane customer service person said that I have the cx policy on my documentation more than average‚Ä¶ and I don‚Äôt want it to be too excessive to annoy the vast majority of clients who are very considerate of our small business.

comments.text: Wr are having this experience and it‚Äôs so frustrating. It‚Äôs in our intake forms at least 3 times (and very obvious) and we talk about it on the first appointment. Yet we have people call us and complain or argue when they see they were charged for their cancel or no shows. We are also 1:1 and it‚Äôs a whole hour of missed work for the business and therapist. It‚Äôs so challenging!

I have a ‚Äú1 Freebee‚Äù rule where I waive it the first time and we have a very direct conversation along the lines of ‚Äúsure I don‚Äôt mind cancelling but just be aware we do have a 24 hour cancellation policy. We will waive it this time but going forward there will be a charge of $xx‚Äù. I note it in their chart and honestly it either doesn‚Äôt happen again or there‚Äôs no argument.

post_text: When transitioning a patient from PT to wellness do you document an initial assessment on day one of wellness? Patients direct access has expired and he still want to work of strength and endurance to prevent reoccurrence of LBP. Please let me know what your protocol is and what documentation you do. TIA

comments.text:
I indicate in the last PT note that the patient will be transitioning to wellness with an explanation as to why. For wellness documentation is minimum. List exercises and any pertinent info. No true need objective tests/measures or a PT assessment.

Also, wellness does not qualify for insurance reimbursement. 

I have a separate set of paperwork that the patient completes indicating that they understand they will be participating in wellness and that it is not eligible for a superbill because it does not qualify for reimbursement.

post_text:
For those that use Jane:
I‚Äôd love to have the option to make a grid with date of session on top and on the left side have a list of manual therapy, exercises, education, etc so I can easily visually see the progression over time. Jane doesn‚Äôt create grids as such. Anyone come up with something similar to organize the note for efficiency and easy visual of interventions? Thanks!

comments.text: Following this because I‚Äôd love the same! Many people have requested the feature to be able to add a table to the notes but unfortunately not every requested feature gets added.

For the current note, I duplicate it from the last note and then put put the new updated at the top. I.e

S:
3/14: back is flared up blah blah
3/7 doing well, blah blah 

O: 
3/14: + FADIR, blah blah
Treatment: xyz

3/7: + FADIR blah blah
Treatment: xyz

It requires a little scrolling but it‚Äôs a nice way to quickly see what I did last time. So for some clients who I‚Äôve seen forever, the notes are LONG as I basically kind of keep adding to the previous one

full_thread_text:
POST: For those that use Jane:
I‚Äôd love to have the option to make a grid with date of session on top and on the left side have a list of manual therapy, exercises, education, etc so I can easily visually see the progression over time. Jane doesn‚Äôt create grids as such. Anyone come up with something similar to organize the note for efficiency and easy visual of interventions? Thanks!

COMMENT 1: Following this because I‚Äôd love the same! Many people have requested the feature to be able to add a table to the notes but unfortunately not every requested feature gets added.

COMMENT 2: For the current note, I duplicate it from the last note and then put put the new updated at the top. I.e

S:
3/14: back is flared up blah blah
3/7 doing well, blah blah 

O: 
3/14: + FADIR, blah blah
Treatment: xyz

3/7: + FADIR blah blah
Treatment: xyz

It requires a little scrolling but it‚Äôs a nice way to quickly see what I did last time. So for some clients who I‚Äôve seen forever, the notes are LONG as I basically kind of keep adding to the previous one

post_text:
Anyone in a cash practice offers massage or MFR sessions in their clinical practice as an additional revenue stream? 

Who provides the service? Do you have a massage therapist on staff or does the PT provide this service if the schedule is not full? 

Any legal aspects to keep in mind? Do patients fill out the same intake forms and payment agreements?

comments.text: I am an OT & John F Barnes Myofascial Release (JFB MFR) is my specialty. This is quite different from other forms of MFR. Lots of people specifically seek this modality especially when traditional therapy has not been successful for them. The legality of having someone working on staff will depend on the state. I operate under my OT license in a direct access state. If you're looking for providers doing JFB MFR check out MFR Insight

I have a massage therapist in my clinic - I provide her the space - she maintains her license and insurance and pays me 20% per client.  She does her own scheduling and handles her clients payments - so it is a win/win for me.  I have referred several patients to her and vice versa!

post_text:
Edited to add i don‚Äôt do credit cards and no EMR as of yet. So it‚Äôs checks cash Zelle, Venmo, and Chase direct pay 

Advice from those who have mobile home/housecall Physical Therapy practices.   How would you eloquently respond to this ? The son is paying for his dad‚Äôs sessions  

Background:  I see 5-6 visits per day 4-5 days per week.    So , everyone before and after has confirmed for Monday.  I also often reach out over the weekend if I don‚Äôt hear back. 
I do have a 24 hour cancellation policy that I let slide for this particular client, the first two times.  So, now it‚Äôs $100 for same day cancel , if they don‚Äôt reschedule to an alternate time or day in the same week.  
Also they haven‚Äôt paid last week or this week, but often wait a week to Zelle. So I would want to mention payment upon confirming .

*help me write back please and thank you

comments.text:
Payment always at time of service. Card on file. Patients get 1 pass only.

**"I understand. Please reach out when you're ready to schedule again. In the meantime, we have two sessions overdue. Would you like to take care of the payment via Zelle or credit card?"**

Payment is required at the time of service.

Three strike rule on cancels. If they can‚Äôt work inside of that, your are happy to send them to the clinic down the road.

post_text: Question in regards to documenting levels of assistance with Medicare . Examples as follows: 1) if a therapist needs to bring w/c behind someone for rest breaks (patient is steady)  when walking with FWW what level of assistance is this labeled as (Min A, CGA/SBA) 2) If a therapist needs to navigate the O2 tank while someone is walking steadily with a FWW, what level of assistance is documented? 3) If a therapist has to navigate a catheter during an activity (stairs, walking, picking up objects) and patient is steady , what level of assistance is given ? There is a debate at my clinic on what should be documented with therapist helping with ‚Äòexternal‚Äô things vs what the patient is actually needing help during the activity. Hopefully this makes sense. Thanks everyone  for your feedback.

comments.text:
You can also document SBA walking with maxA for managing O2/catheter etc. 
The wheelchair example, I agree with the above example of how far they can go independently. What happens if you don't have the chair? Can they independently find somewhere to rest? Do they fall? Or is it out of convenience/meeting rehab goals so you can push to their limits and have the chair ready?

It would depend on necessity and my goal for the treatment. 

In the second case I would document that as CGA/SBA and note I assisted with O2 tank. Realistically this patient needs to have a discussion with their pulmonologist to get a portable concentrator since it‚Äôs nearly impossible for a person to to use a FWW and O2 tank safely unless it‚Äôs hooked or adhered to the FWW. 

In a similar case, if I had to carry a FWW up stairs for my patient during stair training with CGA otherwise, then I would document as Min A and note it was for equipment due to a specific deficit limiting them from performing independently.

post_text:
This was requested from a former client?

‚ÄúCould we ask for a ‚Äúsuper bills‚Äù coded with the accident as the reason for your us needing your specialty?‚Äù

Is this actually a thing?

comments.text: There are icd 10 codes that look at causes. My favorite is attacked by a duck W61.61.  That being said your treatment notes should have the history that shows this.  If the note is already done personally I would not go back and change my documentation.

If I'm understanding this correctly, it sounds like they want you to out on the superbill that services are related to an accident?

Superbill only has the icd-10 and cpt codes. Superbills don't justify medical necessity or cause. That's what the treatment note is for.if it is related to an accident then your documentation should indicate that.

full_thread_text:
POST: This was requested from a former client?

‚ÄúCould we ask for a ‚Äúsuper bills‚Äù coded with the accident as the reason for your us needing your specialty?‚Äù

Is this actually a thing?

COMMENT 1: There are icd 10 codes that look at causes. My favorite is attacked by a duck W61.61.  That being said your treatment notes should have the history that shows this.  If the note is already done personally I would not go back and change my documentation.

COMMENT 2: If I'm understanding this correctly, it sounds like they want you to out on the superbill that services are related to an accident?

Superbill only has the icd-10 and cpt codes. Superbills don't justify medical necessity or cause. That's what the treatment note is for.if it is related to an accident then your documentation should indicate that.

post_text:
Topic- cancellation policy.

I‚Äôm curious others who have a cash business and their cancellation policy.(full disclosure, I am new to the business side of PT) what do people do when patients cancel bc they are sick and cx day of? Still hold them to the policy, or try to accommodate them?

comments.text:
Case by case basis.  

In the past month I‚Äôve more same day (less than 24 hour) cancels than I‚Äôve had in the past 3 years combined. Flu A and B are both rampant around where I live and I don‚Äôt want people coming in sick so I haven‚Äôt been charging for them. 

My clients know if they cancel I probably can‚Äôt get them in again for a month so they‚Äôre usually really good about coming in. 

My policy is:
‚Ä¢less than 24 hours notice = 50% of the appointment cost
‚Ä¢less than 4 hours notice or no notice =100% of the appointment cost (this one I always charge, has to be a very significant situation for me to waive)
Sickness and family emergencies are given grace. Otherwise 1 warning then charge. Ours is $50

post_text: Any recommendations on a documentation program for a start up cash based mobile business?

comments.text:
What‚Äôs your goals? Really depends on where you want to go. If you just want to side hustle forever then just use a hippa compliant version of google workspace. 

If you have intentions to make this the main thing then I‚Äôd bite the bullet and get an emr. 

Jane app and PTEverywhere are likely the 2 main ones you will see recommended.

post_text:
Update: thank you everyone for the feedback. After your feedback I sent an invoice via certified mail (so they couldn‚Äôt say they didn‚Äôt receive it). I also sent them a message letting them know I was cancelling their next appointment as I hadn‚Äôt heard from them, that the equipment needed to be returned by the end of this coming week (they could just leave it in a bag by the office door) and that if it wasn‚Äôt returned and the outstanding balance wasn‚Äôt paid I would be going to the PD for theft of the equipment and moving forward with filing against them in small claims court.  That was enough for them to resume communications. 

They‚Äôve agreed in writing to return the equipment. I‚Äôm hopeful I‚Äôll get paid too. They did send a vague threat of negative review which will suck if that happens.  I‚Äôm still glad I took actions to hold my boundary instead of just letting it go.  

Any 100% private pay providers ever have a patient steal a session? Does anyone know what channels I have for recourse? I‚Äôm in NH if that makes a difference. 

This is a first for me in 11 years. 
I usually make sure people have a credit card on file. In fact my system requires one to book an appointment online but every now and then I‚Äôll schedule a new patient over the phone and forget to get a card.  Still nothing like this has ever happened to me before.

The patient in question came in for an eval. I verbally told them on the phone when they scheduled that I don‚Äôt take insurance and my price. They also got an email with the appointment confirmation stating that I don‚Äôt take insurance.  They signed 2 forms before the appointment stating that I don‚Äôt take insurance and they are responsible for payment at the time of service.  

We get to the end of a 2.5 hour eval (I specialize in PTSD and chronic/complex issues) and when I asked what card they‚Äôd like to use they told me to bill insurance.  When I reminded them I don‚Äôt take insurance they told me they lost their wallet.  I asked about Venmo, PayPal, Apple Pay, etc and they said they don‚Äôt have any of those.  

I sent them an invoice through email hoping they would pay it.  We actually communicated by text for about 4 days after the appointment so I was hopeful that maybe they would actually pay.  It‚Äôs been over 2 weeks now and I‚Äôm being ghosted.  No response via phone, email, or text anymore.

If it makes a difference I also loaned them a piece of my equipment to use and then bring back at their next session. I‚Äôm kicking myself for not getting my equipment back once they asked me to bill insurance and said they lost their wallet.  I just got so flustered and was late for my next patient that I couldn‚Äôt get the words out.  So I also need to either get my equipment back or charge them to replace it.

comments.text:
Honestly for one time I'd eat the cost to avoid the stress and cost of the collections/court.  I had one patient that acknowledged the cost of a 20% coinsurance, signed papers, then refused to pay and it carried on. It was around the holidays last year and was somewhere between $100-200 due. She was very chronic and had some mental involvement with ptsd and a lot of ups and downs. Treatment was going great and then it was like she snapped about all kinds of things and said her psychiatrist wrote off her private due charges. I said it was illegal for me to write off insurance agreements.  In agreement with my insurance assistant, I ultimately wrote it off that one time as "uncollectable" instead of taking her to small claims after trying many times to collect payment. I called the referring doctor and discussed the situation as well. I was upset about it for a little while but the continuation of pressing further wasn't worth it. 

With the equipment...it depends. Sorry you had that experience. Patient avoidance behavior is really tough. I agree on pay before.

I had this happen once. The eval was 1.5 hours and super complicated guy and he kept complaining that my table wasn‚Äôt padded enough. Then-said to invoice him-which I did and he didn‚Äôt pay. When I  reached out he was angry about the table and the fact that I asked him questions about what he wanted to do but could not do due to his injury (a subjective interview!!) and threatened to report me to the board. 

While the board report wouldn‚Äôt have mattered since I didn‚Äôt do anything wrong-it was still something I really didn‚Äôt want to go thru. 

I just let the payment go. I try to reflect back and see if I missed red flags w him üö© 

Hope karma does its job!

post_text: I am a PT in Florida looking to do some cash based treatments at my CrossFit gym. I was wondering if I could get some insight into some basics of the legal components of how to do this, especially for dry needling.

comments.text: Yo answer question specifically For DN. They would need to sign a consent form prior. Make sure you sanitize the area and Carry a sharps container.

Check with your state practice act. I think some vary slightly but most require a signed informed consent prior to txt, certain amount of experience may be required, and I think some require screening the patient prior to txt. My attorney said she had a PT client lose her license because she didn‚Äôt screen prior to needling B UT and patient ended up with a pneumothorax. The state (not sure which state) took license away because no screen was performed despite documentation for proper needling technique and needle placement. My state doesn‚Äôt require a screen but I do a quick one anyway now. She advised good documentation of the signed informed consent, screening, for needles used/how many, muscles treated, and response to tx. 

Hope this helps!

full_thread_text:
POST: I am a PT in Florida looking to do some cash based treatments at my CrossFit gym. I was wondering if I could get some insight into some basics of the legal components of how to do this, especially for dry needling.

COMMENT 1: Yo answer question specifically For DN. They would need to sign a consent form prior. Make sure you sanitize the area and Carry a sharps container.

COMMENT 2: Check with your state practice act. I think some vary slightly but most require a signed informed consent prior to txt, certain amount of experience may be required, and I think some require screening the patient prior to txt. My attorney said she had a PT client lose her license because she didn‚Äôt screen prior to needling B UT and patient ended up with a pneumothorax. The state (not sure which state) took license away because no screen was performed despite documentation for proper needling technique and needle placement. My state doesn‚Äôt require a screen but I do a quick one anyway now. She advised good documentation of the signed informed consent, screening, for needles used/how many, muscles treated, and response to tx. 

Hope this helps!

Edit: I work with children so their parents are millennials and younger.

post_text: For those of you that do not work with insurances and provide cash based services such as dry needling, taping, manipulation techniques, and other holistic health and wellness/pain management services, what do you typically label your invoices for and what type of documentation are you using for both liability protection and reference points (whether that‚Äôs for your patients personal information or for a repeat customer to track modalities and treatments utilized)? This is a bit of a run on question, so I apologize for that! Just wanting to make sure everything is covered before I start marketing this part of my business. Thank you in advance!

comments.text: I use Healthie. I document in a free text daily note for most visits. It has forms you can make templates of you want.

I use Google docs (for business with BAA in place) and write a SOAP note for each session documenting what I did. I also record what CPT codes cover what I did, what ICD-10 I'm treating for, length of visit, and fee charged.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those of you that do not work with insurances and provide cash based services such as dry needling, taping, manipulation techniques, and other holistic health and wellness/pain management services, what do you typically label your invoices for and what type of documentation are you using for both liability protection and reference points (whether that‚Äôs for your patients personal information or for a repeat customer to track modalities and treatments utilized)? This is a bit of a run on question, so I apologize for that! Just wanting to make sure everything is covered before I start marketing this part of my business. Thank you in advance!

COMMENT 1: I use Healthie. I document in a free text daily note for most visits. It has forms you can make templates of you want.

COMMENT 2: I use Google docs (for business with BAA in place) and write a SOAP note for each session documenting what I did. I also record what CPT codes cover what I did, what ICD-10 I'm treating for, length of visit, and fee charged.

There‚Äôs so much noise in the Rehab coaching and entrepreneur space and honestly it makes me want to stay more quiet because noise is exhausting and confusing.

It‚Äôs hard to know where to turn and who to trust and what‚Äôs real vs exaggerated and I‚Äôve seen a lot of people who have big goals get chewed up and spit out. 

These are typically people who have a mission and heart for service and are convinced that the only way towards joy and fulfillment in their life and business is to drive revenue. 

One of our values and missions at Uncaged is to help people build counter cultural businesses. 

Many people in this group have that same desire. They love their profession but hate the system they have to work in and feel like entrepreneurship is their only path forward. 

If that‚Äôs you, be careful who you‚Äôre following and who you surround yourself with. If your focus is building a counter cultural, values based business then surround yourself by others doing the same. 

If that‚Äôs you, join our traction week starting next Wednesday where we‚Äôll walk through the process of building a counter cultural business that allows you to stay true to who you are.

If you‚Äôre interest comment ‚Äútraction‚Äù and we‚Äôll get you more details

comments.text: Traction!
Traction

**Here at UNCAGED CLINICIAN, we are proud to be partners with JANEAPP.**

*Here is a helpful message from them on ways to reclaim your "Me Time"! *

*3 ways to reclaim your ‚Äúme time‚Äù*
## Hey, UNCAGED!

Vas from the Jane team here. üëã

We know that as practitioners, your work day doesn‚Äôt always end after you leave the clinic.

When you‚Äôre in the business of caring for people, it‚Äôs not always easy to put your responsibilities aside to focus on ‚Äúme time‚Äù ‚Äî besides, sometimes the work-life balance swings more on the side of work. And that‚Äôs okay!

But as difficult as it may be, prioritizing this time for yourself is crucial for your own well-being *and* for the quality of care you provide.

Here are **3 strategies that can help you reclaim your ‚Äúme time‚Äù** and weave self-care into your personal life:
## **#1: Set clear boundaries**

When the line between working hours and personal time becomes blurry, setting clear boundaries between the two is key.

Set specific start and end times for your workday, and make sure these times are clearly communicated to your patients or clients. Keeping your work laptop at the office and setting up automated after-hours email responses are great ways to build this habit.

You can also schedule personal activities just like you would a patient appointment ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs an evening workout or a task on your to-do list. This not only ensures you have dedicated ‚Äúme time‚Äù, but can also help keep you accountable to use it.

**#2: Evaluate what‚Äôs on your plate**

Take a long hard look at your daily workflow. Is there anything that can be streamlined, delegated, or simply dropped?

Often, we take on more tasks than we need to ‚Äî feeling the pressure to complete those tasks ourselves. But recognize that there are tools and support systems for practitioners that can help reduce, or even eliminate, the workload of these tasks.

#3: Lean on your community

In a profession fueled by the act of giving, it can feel counterintuitive to receive. But in order to care for your patients, you need to first care for yourself.

Start building a reliable network ‚Äî within your clinic, and beyond. Take advantage of a constantly connected online world by seeking out peer community groups and resources. Keep in mind that if you‚Äôre struggling with self-care, your fellow practitioners have likely experienced something similar, so don‚Äôt be afraid to reach out for advice.

When you start putting ‚Äúme time‚Äù on your to-do list, you‚Äôll notice the impact your own well-being has on the quality of care you provide.

To learn more about how Jane helps you take back time for yourself, head over to [Jane](https://meet.jane.app/more-time?utm_medium=uncaged_clinicians&utm_source=ambassador&utm_campaign=more_time_campaign&utm_content=email&utm_term=us_physio) to book a personalized demo.

And, if you‚Äôre looking for a community to lean on, the [Jane App Community Group](https://jane.app/community?utm_medium=email&utm_source=partners&utm_campaign=more_time_campaign&utm_term=all) is a place where health and wellness practitioners and business owners can learn from and support each other. üíôAdd text to your email.

We hope you found these tips from our friends at Jane App helpful.

post_text:
For those of you who use Spry EMR, what has your experience been? What do you like/dislike about it?

Considering switching to it.

Thank you all!

comments.text: We have been with them for a year and half now, switching from WebPT and its been great. The transition process was excellent. The front office/desk portion is great (scheduling, billing, etc.). We've noticed an increase in revenue since switching as well as higher amounts of patients paying their balances, since they receive a text message and email statement. The ability to save a card on file, like a credit card or HSA card has been great as well. We can just bill the copay to that card at the end of each visit. There are so many great features, that as office manager has made my job so much easier. You can check eligibility and benefits from the EMR directly, reducing the need to use other websites and allowing for increased productivity. Spry has been great, I believe you will be very pleased with them. Customer service is friendly and fast, we typically get a response within minutes.
You'll love it. Affordable and yet has all the features we need. We love them. switched from webpt more than a year back and i thank my stars everyday i see those webpt down posts.

post_text:
I am finally creating an LLC in order to treat 2-3 patients a week. Yay! But I have so many questions. I am in Chattanooga, TN and will be treating in a dance studio. Is this the correct order of operations?
1.Get EIN
2.Form LLC
3.Register business with state 
4.File for business license in county 
5.Get liabilty insurance
6.Treat patients

comments.text: If they are treating in a dance studio, it's unlikely they will be seeing Medicare, so that piece might be a moot point. A few things I would add to the list, create a business bank account and get a business only debit card to make taxes much easier,  determine EMR system, create/personalize paperwork for clients - consents, patient policies, intake forms, payment forms, etc. (and remember even if you are cash only, technically you will need a Good Faith Estimate form), and create a policy manual (even if it's just you!) I have 3 studio based clinics and now we have 15 therapists total, so we definitely have to have a policy and procedure manual, but even for my own personal clinic that is just me, I have a document that lists out all my policies -- like cancellation policy for patients, termination policy for patients that aren't a good fit, when I'll do my inventory, how I'll disburse my payments to myself etc. It's one page for my practice, but its helpful to keep me on track! Good luck!
Fellow Chattanooga provider! Get after it!!!

post_text:
Hoping that someone else has encountered this situation... I‚Äôm a PT and am considering renting an office space at a wellness center. They have LMTs, chiropractors, naturopaths, and acupuncturists. It‚Äôs a co-op so everyone working there is technically independent. 

There are front desk staff who answer calls and schedule massages for the LMTs. Less often, they schedule clients for the DCs, NDs, and acupuncturists.  

My issue is that they use the Mind Body program for scheduling. From what I understand, all clinicians and front desk staff can see everyone else‚Äôs schedule and client demographic info.

What questions should I be asking about patient privacy? About the front desk staff? Is there a work around with this program? 

Thanks in advance.

comments.text:
You have an interesting question. You are speaking of a Wellness center instead of a Medical clinic. But there is likely confidential information that could be exposed, which us Therapists see as a HIPPA breach. Really how far do the HIPPA regulations extend? I would think that anything beyond their phone number and address is HIPPA bound. Are you seeing specific Medical information? 

The person who owns the Center and chose such a program is possibly not of the Allied Health/Medical profession.

I‚Äôm in a similar situation where I do PT out of a Pilates studio (where I also teach Pilates). We use Mind Body.  My schedule in Mind Body has my availability and my Pilates clients and when a PT patient is scheduled it simply says ‚ÄúPT‚Äù.  Then I use a separate EMR that no one has access to but me and the studio manager (who is HIPPA) trained.  In that schedule I have the name of the patient on the schedule.  It‚Äôs a pain to maintain two schedules and make sure they are both updated correctly but I haven‚Äôt found a better solution.
