post_text: I started my cash-based mobile vestibular practice in April and thinking about offering a telehealth option. I don‚Äôt have an EMR, I use Google Workspace and just signed up with doxy.me. What do I need to do to set this up? Telehealth patient consent form? Anything else? Thanks in advance!

comments.text: Telehealth and mobile vestibular PT here!  You have to document that you used audio and visual format using doxy.me for telehealth appointments, and you have to document the individual's address at the time of service (okay to say "refer to address in intake paperwork").  You also have to be licensed in the state where the patient is located at the time of the service.

1) You can use Google Workspace as an EMR. Check out Unsubscribed Healthcare on YouTube. 

2) Our state practice act (KY) had information on what they needed us to have on file. Or maybe it was Medicare... Pretty sure it was our practice act though. It was pretty straightforward, just a couple forms and some things to verbally verify at the front of each telehealth session.

post_text: Those of you who are insurance based-how do you handle Initial Evaluations who no show? We have a cancellation policy for current patients and honestly we do really well with compliance once we eval people. But we're in a slump where our initial evaluations are not showing up which is just killing us. Any ideas?

comments.text:
Often times this comes back to the first phone call. 

Are these leads referrals? From advertising ? 

You want the client to excited and ready to come in for a visit. 

Maybe they weren‚Äôt a fit or weren‚Äôt ready to schedule or they have fear doubt and uncertainty about whether this is the next right step for them. 

Has anything changed about your front desk process

Other question would be how far out were they booked? Sometimes more than a week out people will start to no show etc
We call everybody on Fridays for the upcoming week and make sure everything is good to go

Such a great tool;) I have been in this group for a while and should have make the leap sooner;) 

Thank you Hippo Scribe and Yansen Zhou for helping our profession get the job done in a manner that doesn‚Äôt take away from patient care! 

Just use the web browser but pretty easy! Also just used a Rode Microphone clipped to my shirt and once I started the note, I was able to treat hands free.  
I also use it exclusively on my phone.   Transfer to my EMR is just one more step via computer at end of day.  

I make my patients aware of what I am doing and once I get the subjective, I start my manual and I then talk about my plan for the session, interventions and exercises.  Within 5-10 mins of the patient arriving most of my note is completed and I can edit if the sessions doesn‚Äôt go according to plan or patient didn‚Äôt tolerate.

post_text:
I loathe documentation.
This has been a theme throughout my childhood ‚Ä¶.I have always loathed assignments and homework my whole life.  Documentation feels like an extension of this. I treat one on one so I'm always left with documentation at the end of the day. (I know one on one is a gift lol)

I have been using ChatGPT to do as much of the heavy lifting as possible, by making it write patient assessments for me with this GPT

https://[chat.openai.com/g/g-C1fuXSdT4-ai-assessment-](http://chat.openai.com/g/g-C1fuXSdT4-ai-assessment-)writer-pt

hopefully it helps some of you!
Generally curious why our notes are so
monotonous and repetitive but none of us
implement any tools to get them done?

comments.text:
This why I use Comprehend Health to help writes my notes for me in real time as I treat. Every section of my note is completed in real time so I can focus on treating each client 100% of the time. I just check it over at the end to make sure I verbalized everything needed for my note, hit finalize, and my note is complete in seconds. I treat one-on-one as well, so it‚Äôs great knowing that as my last patient leaves I am actually done for the day, evals, daily notes, and progress notes are all done in real time. 

Chat GPT is great, but it isn‚Äôt HIPAA compliant, so you can‚Äôt use it with any real patient info. Having to jump back and forth with chatGPT and manually writing in information so it can then spit something back out, which you have to edit multiple times then copy into your EMR is even more time consuming.

Can someone give me a concrete example of how exactly you use ChatGPT or any AI to assist with documentation, assessments, SOAP notes, etc?  I understand that I can type in the search box something like ‚Äúgive me examples of blog posts for a physical therapy clinic‚Äù but how do you literally do it for documentation? I just can‚Äôt wrap my head around this. I am VERY new to trying to use these platforms too. TIA!

post_text: I have my  mobile based LLC and have a home health agency reach out to contract some of their patients to me, they want to pay $75 for follow up and $100 for eval. I feel like this is very low but wanted to see what you all think. Thank you

comments.text: Way too low. I would not go below 100 for tx and 150 for eval, and that is still low. One of our Therapists in our program on the east coast just negotiated 110 for tx and 165 for eval. No oasis.

This was and still is my business model. Sometimes I negotiate depending on if the HH patient is Medicare or Medicaid and trying to be respectful to the agency who is getting paid peanuts by the state for Medicaid patients. Also can negotiate if a PT vs PTA will be seeing them. Average is PT visit/eval $95 and then I add $30 for SOC/OASIS document. I occasionally lose $ on the PT visits but make it up on the margin of a PTA visit vs pay rate

full_thread_text:
POST: I have my  mobile based LLC and have a home health agency reach out to contract some of their patients to me, they want to pay $75 for follow up and $100 for eval. I feel like this is very low but wanted to see what you all think. Thank you

COMMENT 1: Way too low. I would not go below 100 for tx and 150 for eval, and that is still low. One of our Therapists in our program on the east coast just negotiated 110 for tx and 165 for eval. No oasis.

COMMENT 2: This was and still is my business model. Sometimes I negotiate depending on if the HH patient is Medicare or Medicaid and trying to be respectful to the agency who is getting paid peanuts by the state for Medicaid patients. Also can negotiate if a PT vs PTA will be seeing them. Average is PT visit/eval $95 and then I add $30 for SOC/OASIS document. I occasionally lose $ on the PT visits but make it up on the margin of a PTA visit vs pay rate

post_text: Is anyone using anything that is free (or close to) for documentation? I'm trying to keep start up costs minimal, but maybe then expand into something like Jane. So I'm thinking about using squares free version for scheduling and payments initially, but is there anything basic out there for the documentation (Google doc or word even). The only other thing I'd need is some consent forms, so if anyone has leads on that as well, I would be very greatful! Thanks uncaged community!

comments.text: Healthie

Consider the long term goals for your practice. If growth is in your plan, then it may be more cost effective from a time management perspective to pay for an EMR platform now. Most will handle scheduling, billing, documentation, reports, template builds, super bills, etc. If you wait to make the swap once your business is busy you may not have the luxury of time to setup your EMR the way you want to. 

On that note, I locked in PTEverywhere at a deep discount before I had a single patient. I am so glad that I did. I was able to create templates, scheduling, billing when I had the time to do so and now have access to look back at financial reports and patient data to day 1. 

It cost $48/month. I am exclusively out of network.

full_thread_text:

So I'm thinking about using squares free version for scheduling and payments initially, but is there anything basic out there for the documentation (Google doc or word even). The only other thing I'd need is some consent forms, so if anyone has leads on that as well, I would be very greatful! Thanks uncaged community!

COMMENT 1: Healthie

COMMENT 2: Consider the long term goals for your practice. If growth is in your plan, then it may be more cost effective from a time management perspective to pay for an EMR platform now. Most will handle scheduling, billing, documentation, reports, template builds, super bills, etc. If you wait to make the swap once your business is busy you may not have the luxury of time to setup your EMR the way you want to. 

On that note, I locked in PTEverywhere at a deep discount before I had a single patient. I am so glad that I did. I was able to create templates, scheduling, billing when I had the time to do so and now have access to look back at financial reports and patient data to day 1. 

It cost $48/month. I am exclusively out of network.

post_text:
What do you all have for brick and mortar building security system and entrance door? I am by myself and I don‚Äôt have any front desk staff, I am by appointment only and sometimes the next person comes few minutes early and they use the waiting area, however I am in the treatment room hands on so can‚Äôt always go out to unlocks the doors. However I also don‚Äôt want someone strange walking in to the building? It is an ok neighborhood but there are crimes everywhere? What do you all do? 
Thank you.

comments.text:
I have a similar set up.  I have a security camera in the waiting room that records when there‚Äôs movement and I can review recorded videos and live streaming on an app on my phone. 

I have chimes that sounds when the front door opens. 

I can lock the door between the waiting room and the rest of my office.

A few years ago I had some problems with some really creepy guy patients so I have a few other safety measures too:

Apple Watch because of the press and hold security feature  

Waistband toggle that makes an ear piercing sound if removed from the waistband

And hornet spray (one of my patients that‚Äôs a police officer recommended this). It shoots a stream 20-30 feet and doesn‚Äôt create a cloud that could also affect you.  He said to aim for the eyes.  I have one in my rollie computer desk and a few others in various places around the office.

I wonder if you could use something like Level, depending on the type of door? You could have a standard key lock for full opening and closing and then use a temporary pass for your patients if they show up a few minutes early and want to use the secondary Level lock.

post_text: Aside from PTEverywhere, are there any other programs like this people are using for physical therapy services? I'm mostly interested in the emr, scheduling and legal form stuff they offer. I'm working towards a mobile, cash based practice. Thanks!

comments.text: I use PTEverywhere and it has everything I need and I added a fax line which has been handy, but it is pricey. Once I got the hang of things I felt like I could have used a cheaper platform, but uploading videos of myself explaining topics for lengthier education pieces or things I want them to view and videos of myself doing exercises is easy. I started when there was a promo where it started cheaper as you built a caseload so if you call and do a demo that could be an option. This is kind of quirky, but I actually picked it over Jane because I liked that PT was in the title and how that seemed professionally, but Jane probably uploads your logo like they do and it's not really an issue, just a preference over here. Once PTEverywhere got pricier, I was busier so it wasn't really an issue and I considered switching but that seemed like a hassle and not worth the reduced price.

I used PTeverywhere and liked it but it was expensive.  A lot of people like Jane.  I use Noterro because I can have my wife and I both as PTs for about 90/month.  Thee forms are great, the notes are a little quirky.   Customer support is good

post_text:
Hi everyone!

I've been accepting cash only for PT services but have been getting more people asking if I take HSA/FSA funds so I am considering starting to do that. Is there any additional paperwork I need in order to accept these forms of payment? If accepting HSA/FSA comes with additional rules, does anyone have any good resources outlining them? I am located in NH if the state matters.

comments.text:
I'm also in VA. I've used Square and currently use intakeq. For both systems as long as I'm registered with them as a healthcare provider the client can just process the HSA/FSA as they would a normal credit card. 

There's no additional documentation requirements. Sometimes they may need to submit a superbill for proof the funds were used foe medical/health services, but this hasn't been necessary for any of my clients as my business is registered as healthcare with my payment systems.

I‚Äôm cash based in VA. I use a payment app (HIPPA compliant) called IvyPay

The family puts CC directly into there for payment. It actually also allows the family to put in HSA or FSA accounts if they prefer to pay from those

post_text: Hello! I'm opening my cash based practice next month and am very excited. I've learned a lot from this group but do have a question on how people document transitions to wellness. I already have some clients lined up and one of them wants to be treated for "posture" since they work a desk job and are having pains. Now in my mind posture likely isn't medically necessary and will fall in wellness depending on impairments found, so if you do an eval under PT but determine wellness is more appropriate if any follow ups are necessary, how do you document that transition? Then let's say you're treating a patient with any diagnosis that went to wellness but their symptoms returned, how would you document the transition back to PT? Or am I over thinking this and you just set up 2 separate cases? Thanks in advance!

comments.text: I use Jane for all documentation, even wellness visits. You can create any type of form you want. Patients have one chart but you can see PT eval, PT follow up, PT discharge and then Wellness visit. I do billing and payment through the app as well so its all in one place. (I am cash based)

Posture isn‚Äôt the icd 10. The pain is. The posture is a likely soutce of the pain. People don‚Äôt go to the ER with heart attack. They go with chest pain. So if there is affiliated pain it would be considered medically necessary ‚Ä¶. Right??

post_text:
Hi. I met some women who are writing an e-book for post-partum Moms.  More regarding depression, lactation, tongue tied infants, etc and their personal experience.  The goal would be for them to eventually monetize on this e-book.  They asked me to contribute to a chapter on pelvic health, in which it would be co written and reviewed by me, Pelvic Health Physical Therapist.  They would link my practice, my name and their IG posts to my practice.  They also plan to do webinars, with me, that would promote my clinic and some local in person sessions in the community.  

Now, how should I get compensated?  

They have expressed that they are limited in funds when I asked regarding payment and the marketing would be exposure/benefit.  Any suggestions or advice is appreciated.  Thank You

comments.text: I'm not sure chapter authors are paid very much...my cardiopulm PT professor told me once he was paid $300 to contribute a chapter to a text book...not sure if that is typical or not.

You usually don‚Äôt get paid to add a chapter in a book. You get to call yourself an author after this and promote it as YOUR book too. You get to give it away, sale it or whatever else you want to do with it. Many times with these kinds of books you are asked to pay to contribute. If they‚Äôre not asking for money and they have a decent following, I would do it!! It is going to open doors for you. ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm Monica! Im a PT and local author who wrote this chapter on women‚Äôs health. I would love to leave a couple copies here for your clients to help educate them. Would that be ok?‚Äù 

Yep!!!! 

Sometimes you can even work out between all the authors to have a separate cover for each author to promote them. 

There are so many possibilities with this kind of collaboration. Just do it. You can write a chapter in a week. 

Here‚Äôs how. 

1) mind map your chapter 
What‚Äôs it going to be about?
What are the 5-10 things everyone needs to know about it?
What questions do people have?
What problems are you solving?
What is the solution? 

2) write or dictate it
3) edit it
4) send it to the other author

BOOM YOURE AN AUTHOR! 

And now you‚Äôre the AUTHORITY!

post_text:
Those that transitioned from mobile to clinic: what are some unexpected fixed expenses that you had besides from rent/utilities/tax/renter insurance 

Thank you!

comments.text:
What Jaimie Gant said.  

Also, I definitely prefer to have admin in the office so they can scan, print, check in, schedule, remind of appts, sometimes open the door for people (our door can be heavy for some), mine also cleans between sessions, keeps a running list of supplies needed, and keeps the whole place clean

water cooler station (mine is inserted in the bottom which is nice but it can provide hot, cool, cold;

equipment that may not want to be or able to be with you for mobile equipment including racks for them, mirrors on wall, railings

signage (windows, outside if you get a space, parking if needed, decals for walls

furniture: decor, tables, chairs (waiting room, treatment spaces), treatment table(s)

LOVED moving from mobile to B&M.  I can see more people, not as much wear and tear on my car, and have more ability to help people further with the equipment needs, not take time with set up/take down with mobile, etc

(hopefully that helps!)

Depending on what‚Äôs included in your lease/how the space is set up: internet, things for the bathroom (TP, hand soap, paper towels), cleaning supplies, office supplies (again, depending on what you need - printer, paper, pens/pencils, etc)

post_text:
TLDR: Don't forget to make sure you have DMARC, DKIM, and SPF setup on your domain DNS (where your URL is hosted). This not only applies for ppl using third parties to send newsletters, etc but also when using any branded email address. These are to prevent email spoofing and verify the senders are who they say they are. Those who don't have them can now encounter deliverability issues as of Feb 2024.

Here's a little bit about it from constant contact: https://knowledgebase.constantcontact.com/email-digital-marketing/articles/KnowledgeBase/7644-What-is-DMARC?lang=en_US

This first started as being for accounts who send 5000 emails per day, however most emails clients are now making it highly recommended or even required. You might see an alert popup up on logging in, don't ignore it.

If you don't add these, constant contact is just one that will change your sender address to one of theirs until you do. 

Here's what these things are in a nutshell:

Imagine you're at a costume party where everyone wears a mask, making it tough to tell who's who. This situation is a bit like the internet's email system: it's easy for someone to disguise themselves as someone else and send you emails pretending to be your bank, your friend, or your boss. That's where DMARC, DKIM, and SPF step in, acting as the party's bouncers, verifying the identity of each guest.

SPF (Sender Policy Framework) is like a guest list at the party entrance. It checks if the sender's email server is on the list of approved servers for that domain. If the server isn't on the list, SPF tells the email system, "This one's trying to crash the party!" and can prevent the email from reaching your inbox.

DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail) is like a secret handshake. It uses a digital signature attached to the email, ensuring that the message really comes from where it says it does and hasn't been tampered with along the way. Think of it as checking if a guest knows the secret handshake before letting them mingle.

DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) watches over SPF and DKIM like a head bouncer. It uses the results from both to decide what to do with an email that fails the checks. DMARC can tell the email system to do nothing, quarantine the email, or reject it outright. It also sends reports back, saying who tried to get in, so the party planners can adjust their guest list and handshake as needed.

These three work together to make sure that the only emails reaching your inbox are from the people who they claim to be from, keeping the party crashers out and making the email world a safer place to communicate.

Happy to answer any questions or drop links to instructions for any hosts below.
full_thread_text:

post_text: If you hire a physical therapist and guarantee them 32 hours a week(per their requested hours they want to work), how long do you expect it takes to get their caseload to build to a full caseload? What if their cancellation rate is awful(averages 40%) 90 days in? What would you do?

comments.text: are appointments being confirmed? are late fees and late cancels/no shows being collected? is there a reason why their patients are not being retained?

Who is taking the cancellation calls from patients?  Is it the therapist or an office manager?  

I would look at how those conversations are conducted.  For example, If a patient is calling to say they are running late, have to bring their kid with them, on their period (thinking pelvic health)  are they encouraged to still come on in or are they just immediately cancelled?  Make sure the person taking those calls is trying to recapture the visit that day or that week whenever possible.

post_text: Hi! My website is made on Wix and I‚Äôd like to add some sort of lead gen (like an e book or info sheet) that can be emailed automatically when it is clicked on. Is this possible on Wix ?

comments.text: Wix can tech do it but I'd recommend integrating another service to do automations like that. You'll need an email service if you don't have one. Mailer lite is my first rec for a free option with automation. Convertkit is my top pick, but no free option. Those services can fully integrate with wix, have sign up forms, and will deliver your lead magnet/freebie.

Hi Tara Galgano Phaff Absolutely! On Wix, you can integrate a lead generation form using Wix Forms. Simply create a form for users to fill out, and then set up an automated email response with the e-book or info sheet attached. Wix offers various features to help you achieve this seamlessly. If you need more guidance, feel free to ask!

post_text: Do you pay for documentation time? Why or why not? Does that change if all your treatments are 1 on 1? Does it change based on patient population? Or what EMR you use? I need guidance

comments.text: Nope. Documentation shouldn‚Äôt take long. 1 on 1 pelvic health clinic

It‚Äôs just me so far but I plan to. How many industries get away with requiring work to be done but not paying the employee to do that work? 
It also really punishes neurodivergent clinicians who physically can‚Äôt just knock out documentation quickly. 
I think there are way to balance it when you pay for that time, allowing a certain percentage of paid time for admin tasks including documentation, communication with referral sources, etc. 
the practices I‚Äôve seen who schedule paid documentation time also seem to have happy employees who aren‚Äôt burning out like crazy.

post_text: What is a nice way to send an email about cancellations? How should I nicely introduce a cancellation policy? Do I have to have current patients sign it or just let them know? Any ideas?! I keep getting ditched these last two weeks, I know people are busy right now, but still. My time needs to be respected.

comments.text: Following because I have a similar issue. My plan was to institute a new policy effective Jan 1 - cancellation/no show policy and a fee for nonpayment of invoices after a certain time period, as I‚Äôm also having an issue with that, albeit a much smaller problem than the cancelations.

I give out a form that the clients sign with initial paperwork stating that my cancelation policy is a $100 fee for less that 24 hours notice. The first time a client cancels without rescheduling I remind them that they sign this form in the initial paperwork and tell them that this time I will not charge them but any future cancellations will be charged. I also make them understand that by them canceling last
Minute they are preventing another client from receiving care. People usually think that is reasonable and will respect your time going forward. If you have a repeat offender that never keeps appointments I would just tell them that you can not keep them on your schedule but we happy to try to accommodate same day visit if they call and you have availability. For what it‚Äôs worth I‚Äôm cash pay except for Medicare

If you have a repeat offender that never keeps appointments I would just tell them that you can not keep them on your schedule but we happy to try to accommodate same day visit if they call and you have availability. For what it‚Äôs worth I‚Äôm cash pay except for Medicare

post_text: I am a PT and have a mobile, cash based wellness business as a side hustle. I'm planning on going full time in my business soon. In order to boost business I plan on switching my model from wellness to PT. I want to remain cash only (no insurance, no Medicare). I'll accept payment upfront and provide patient's a superbill. My question is: what else do I need to have in place that I'm not thinking of? I already have: LLC, liability insurance, consent form, superbill template (although not currently used). Anything else? Thanks!

comments.text:
Either documentation that you create or an emr system that you purchase.  

Other intake such as medical history form.

It‚Äôs going back a bit since I worked without an emr but I believe a plan of care and daily notes are separate from a superbill.  

If direct access, follow your state guidelines on signage, dated signatures and limitations (for example California only allows 13 visits or 45 calendar days)

post_text:
I am a mobile PT who sees several private clients at their homes. On Friday, I arrived to my client's home (~25 min away) that I have been seeing regularly, 2-3x/week since June, with minimal to no scheduling/cancellation issues. As I pulled into their complex, they texted me (at 11:22 for an 11:30 appt) to cancel as apparently the client was ill. I believe that to actually be the case, but wasn't given any more details besides that. I decided to enforce a small fee (less than the cancellation policy fee/session cost, because it was illness related) to cover my childcare fees as I had set up a babysitter to allow me to get to the session (which was my only session of the day) and I had already arrived. I called and explained this to the patient/spouse, and they paid, but I feel maybe were not happy about this. 

 I am mom, and also a human and totally understand things happen! I have had clients cancel same day, several hours before due to legitimate reasons and not enforced my cancellation policy. I am curious what people do about a cancellation that occurs if you've already arrived to the client's home for a session? Do you just enforce your regular cancellation policy as if it were a no-show?  My clients are very committed and respectful, so I think this is a one-off, but just wanted to gain some perspective from everyone. Thank you!

comments.text: Did this client know about your cancellation fee? Do you go over this when you do your initial paperwork?

Since you said that the cancellation fee/policy is in your paperwork and reviewed with the client, then I would 100% charge this. I am also mobile and if someone was to cancel with 8 minutes to go to their appt, I would charge them my full cancellation fee. The only way I wouldn't do this if it was a super extenuating circumstance, i.e. they got into a car accident on the way home from errands. From your example, this client very likely knew they were ill before 11:22am - if they woke up at 9am and felt ill, they should have notified you as early as possible. I get it that some circumstances are different, but they need to respect your time.

full_thread_text:

post_text: Hellonote users- When you are doing a re-certification and are planning to bill a re-eval do you use the "re=certification" note type and just bill part of it as a re-eval;  or do you use the "re-evaluation" note type?? Thanks in advance! Cross posted.

comments.text: Hey friend! So if you are doing a re-cert to extend the plan of care past the original expiration date (because I'm assuming they are making progress), then you do not bill for a re-evaluation. You can bill for ther act or self care or whatever you think the session would fall under. A re-eval should only be billed if you are re-doing the whole plan of care because there has been a significant change in status, such as a new diagnosis or a hospitalization for something. Re-eval charges are hardly ever billed. Hope that makes sense!

I've always done recertification note then billed for whatever I did. I guess depends why you're doing a re-eval. But the recert should work. Idk what the re-eval note type looks like as I've never used it

Thinking about switching to putting our intake forms on the iPad, we have like 10 pages of intake forms for all of our treatment consent forms and cancellation policy and everything. It‚Äôs been such a waste of paper and the ink/paper is expensive.

Have any of you used an iPad for intake forms and have you found your elder patients to be able to do it on there? I was worried some of them would have difficulty using it via iPad?

If I were to put the intake forms on the iPad. What app or software could I use for that?

Thanks again!

comments.text: I use Jane app and send my intake forms prior to the appointment. If the haven‚Äôt filled it out, then I bring my iPad for them to fill it out

LOVE intakeQ ($40ish/month no contract for forms only). I just switched over and it‚Äôs so user friendly for the provider and patient. I can send the link to complete forms to their phone or email and it‚Äôs all electronic. Plus creating the forms was simple or you can pay $10/form for the system to create it for you. I opted in to their practice management software instead which is forms and scheduling/billing ($75/month no contract) just due to how simple and user friendly it is so when I schedule an eval they automatically get the intake forms and/or a zoom link for virtual clients. Plus I set it up to automatically bill the patients since I do private pay but used to use insurance so it could bill their co-pays and integrated with office ally easily. My older clients do it with a breeze! Don‚Äôt underestimate them, esp when the systems are more simplified now. Try it for free. You don‚Äôt even need to put your billing info in during the two week trial so can get a real feel for it. Love this one, Hate clinic source

post_text:
Hi Everyone,

I'm in need of a pep talk or any advice. 
We've just surpassed 1 year of business and have been on track with our goals. 
However, recently, we've had SO MANY cancellations. It's starting to wear me down. Both myself and my other therapist on staff are dealing with this and it's making me feel like I'm doing something wrong or people don't think we are worth It. Since August we've had at least a few a week (minimum) or shuffling around the schedule. I know I shouldn't focus on that because we've also had so many great wins but sometimes it's hard and I want to minimize this going forward. As a side we are all cash pay. 
Thanks for your help!

comments.text:
First off, that can be completely normal this time of the year. You are doing great! If you are on track with your goals, then just focus on the wins and less on the losses. 

If the cancellations become a consistent problem, then go back and focus on communication and how the plan of care is communicated during the evaluation and during each treatment to the clients. That can usually clear up cancellation problems.

So the question is what are you doing about it?
...
Once you acknowledge the problem the next step is developing a system to resolve it and prevent it. 
...
There are lots of ways to fix this problem. 
...
Some therapists will impose strict cancel fees, others will secure payment in advance. 
...
Personally I find that this is a signal that my marketing is targeting the wrong patients. When I stopped treating low back pain referrals and focused on post op TKR referrals my cancel/no show rate dropped to near zero. 
...
It is normal to feel frustrated, but that is when you put on your business owner hat and realize you can control the situation and make a change.

post_text:
There are two ditches on both sides of the road to avoid when growing your business:

Left ditch - "I can figure it out on my own." That is fueled by pride/ego and can get us in trouble. It's always healthiest to stay open to learning at all times. 

Right ditch - Over-consuming all information that you can get your hands on. Many people read books and absorb information that isn't helpful in the stage of business they are in, and steers them away from implementation of the right things. 

The heart of this post comes from hearing many people tell me that they have pre-ordered Alex Hormozi's $100M Leads. Every book he puts out is fantastic, no doubt...BUT here is the question I ask each time: Is that what you NEED to be reading to get you to your next level of growth?

If not, be disciplined enough to pick up the RIGHT book.
So, why is this important?

Because I've literally seen practice owners who REALLY just need to hire another PT, pick up a book like that and get side tracked for MONTHS because they are trying to implement the wrong thing.

That book at the RIGHT time for the RIGHT business, Im sure will be exceptional, but really the PT in the example above just needs to focus on hiring, and learning how to do so properly.

Stay on the road at all costs! Don't get distracted and veer yourself off the road only to realize months later how far you have gone off the road. 

You can do this! This is just my reminder to stay focused and avoid the two ditches.

comments.text: Comparison is how Satan works in business‚Ä¶especially for believers. He knows we naturally have desires to have more or do more. When we think we need more or something different comparison starts to run our business and gets us off track
Great reminder!!!üí™üèºü•∞

post_text:
Looking for advice on publishing a special populations wellness book. I have the bulk of the content done but am stuck on a few aspects:

-how much time/money to invest on formatting and graphics until I figure out if it will be self publishing vs sending manuscripts to publishers (who I assume would give input and have their own team to assist with that). 
-Is Amazon KDP what others of you used or are there better self publishing options if that‚Äôs the recommended route? 
-Do I need to set up an LLC now (or ever) just for publishing? I worry since the book is exercise/wellness despite multiple disclaimers it could be a liability. 

Thanks for any guidance. I feel stuck and really am hoping to get this out.

comments.text: We did a session on this at a summit in June.. where are you at in the process. KDP is definitely a great route to start with.

I just published my first book last week, went through KDP since I was a newbie at this. Didn't check out other self-publishing options; needed to get it out. I can answer a couple of your questions: 
--I wanted a good quality book, so I invested $$ in editing and cover design/graphics and illustrations. With self-publishing, your deadlines are your own, not dictated by a publisher (pros and cons for that). Find a graphics person who understands and follows copyright laws! Found out that the formatting had to be done by me or my husband as I couldn't give account access to my cover artist. THAT took a long time and energy. On the flip side, I don't have to pay any publishing, printing, or distribution costs with KDP. 
--I published in KDP as an individual author and not through my business. Thought that doing this would allow me to use it as an educator and advocate and not just my PT clinic's product. Hope that makes sense!
--I get it, it is easy to get stuck at this phase. Trust me that this Uncaged group is great at helping you get unstuck! Right Sharon Gaffney-Wisnewski Josh Payne?? üôÇ

post_text:
In my post from today, multiple people asked me to share **my top 5 books** that I've read of all time that were valuable in me growing in business.

Overall, before I get into it I must say that there is no other book that has impacted me more as an entrepreneur than the Bible (Read Proverbs if you don't believe me üòÑ) . It is packed with useful knowledge that God has laid out to help us to realize how to run effective businesses in the marketplace. 

These are the FIVE OTHER books that I have read that have made the biggest impact on me and our businesses. I'm also going to share what its helpful for as well. I believe strongly in reading a specific book with a specific goal in mind. This requires us to know ourselves, know our businesses, and be self-aware enough to know what needs to be worked on in the business. 

Here we go! (in no particular order)
1. Marketing and Selling: ***Book Yourself Solid* by Michael Port**.

It's a classic that I still come back to. I've read all the modern books out there on marketing, and this is the one with principles that are tried and true. 

2. Finances in Business: ***Profit First* by Mike Michalowicz**. 

Simple method to get your finances under control, and to save you years of headaches with your finances. 

3. Mindset specific for entrepreneurs: ***Gap Or The Gain* by Dan Sullivan and Dr. Benjamin Hardy. **

It will radically shift your perspective of how to think as a business owner. 

4. Managing and understanding your team/people: **6 Types of Working Genius by Patrick Lencioni**. 

Incredible book and testing system to understand how each person on your team plays a part in the overall function of the company. 

5. Scaling a business: ***Traction* by Gino Wickman. **

I read this book too early as a solopreneur from a recommendation from a friend and I really wasn't able to grasp the importance. When reading it years later, it was profound. The right book at the wrong time isn't very helpful. The right book at the right time can work wonders in a business. If you aren't in a position to scale yet, I wouldn't suggest reading it until you are (just my opinion). 

Hope this is helpful to you! üëä

comments.text: Woah and I actually missed a sixth one that has made a massive impact on Uncaged Clinician as a whole: The Carpenter by John Gordon. Incredible book that teaches the most impactful values that a business can have!

I think it depends most on what hinders your growth which can vary from person to person.  My most impactful books to date have all to do with personal growth and mindset.  

Just shedding some light for us outliers out there üôãüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Clarence ‚ÄúKelly‚Äù Johnson coined the principle ‚ÄúKeep it simple, stupid (KISS)‚Äù in World War II when he helped his skunk works team to keep it simple when it came to the design of their top-secret stealth jets.

ùêàùêü ùêäùêûùê•ùê•ùê≤ ùêâùê®ùê°ùêßùê¨ùê®ùêß ùêúùêöùêß ùê¨ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùê•ùê¢ùêüùê≤ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêíùêë-ùüïùüè ùêÅùê•ùêöùêúùê§ùêõùê¢ùê´ùêù ùê¨ùê≠ùêûùêöùê•ùê≠ùê° ùê´ùêûùêúùê®ùêßùêßùêöùê¢ùê¨ùê¨ùêöùêßùêúùêû ùê£ùêûùê≠, ùê≤ùê®ùêÆ ùêúùêöùêß ùêúùêûùê´ùê≠ùêöùê¢ùêßùê•ùê≤ ùê¨ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùê•ùê¢ùêüùê≤ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê∞ùêöùê≤ ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêúùê®ùê¶ùê©ùêöùêßùê≤ ùê´ùêÆùêßùê¨.

I believe this goes for your‚Ä¶

Pricing.
Marketing.
Sales Process.
Documentation.
And much more.

The longer I am in business, the more I‚Äôm reminded to ‚ÄúKeep it simple, stupid‚Äù. üòÉ

comments.text: Love this example Josh! Kelly Johnson was so ahead of his time despite the simplicity of this approach. The P-38 Lightning, P-80 Shooting start, F-104 Starfighter, and the SR-71 are all technical marvels

If you work with any insurance companies and aren't implementing RTM into your practice, you're missing out on thousands of dollars of extra income per year that is 99% passive with the correct software once you setup the workflow in your system.

I've been utilizing SaRa Health https://www.sarahealth.io/ for RTM and I cannot say enough good things about their software and development team working with them has been an absolute breeze. It is completely hands off once you take the 30 seconds to setup the patient in the system. They take everything from their from messaging the patient and even tell you what to document in your note and what codes to bill. They notify you when to check in with a patient if a response is "abnormal" and give me a summary of responses over the past month.

This is a must with any practice that bills Medicare and private insurance.

post_text:
Hello!

So we have a new PT starting in august. Really just waiting for her license to come in and she can start instantly. So I‚Äôm just guessing it hopefully comes in mid august. So maybe august 14 or august 21.

So the week of the 14th I have 7 new eval‚Äôs scheduled. I‚Äôm really hoping to be able to give these new evals to our new PT. So I wanted to re schedule them to the following week where the new PT will have her license in and she can start with them.

But i dont know how to call the patients who are already scheduled, who will have been waiting for almost 3-4 weeks to be seen that I want to move them back another week?

Because if they stay on my schedule it will be very hard to get them scheduled for follow up appointments.

comments.text:
personally, if these patients waited that long, they want to see you!  To schedule them with someone isn't fair; but you may also lose patients- because why wait longer if they can't see you to begin with?
 Maybe what you can do, especially if the new clinican is a new grad is have them come "shadow" the day you're loaded with evals. 
This way patients can also see who else is in the clinic.

We had similar situations happen at a few clinics where I worked. Some patients only wanted to see one clinician because of past word of mouth and that's okay. 
However, you can use this time to let patients know, we have someone new coming in, to help with my caseload...talk that therapist up! It may work to your advantage vs rescheduling patients to a later week.

You do the evals then hand off.  Have the new therapist observe and type up the eval if you are overwhelmed.   It‚Äôs much more important to get those patients in the door to start.   If patients have to wait 4-5 weeks for PT they are much more likely to go elsewhere or no show.   ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

post_text:
Posting this anonymously due to personal reasons on a simple question.

For those covering a clinic due to an urgent unforseen emergency, and are documenting on paper, do you truly document on paper or a word document?

As a background, I am helping a friend/colleague out who is out due to an unfortunate event. I've worked in the clinic before so it's not a new atmosphere but it's been a while.  Since I'm not in their EMR system and just "covering" to help keep patients going, we thought doing paper notes would be okay. 

Has anyone been in a similar situation? What have you done, you know too CYA üòÇ

comments.text: I would think you would document on something be it paper or a word document and put it in their EMR as a "late entry" and have them keep the originals with the original license/signature for their records to CYA and theirs.
Or ask the owner to contact the EMR company to give you temporary access - I'm sure this comes up for others as well. You'll need to be able to review charts of patients your are picking up as well.

post_text:
Hello! We are hiring our first employee for admin work (answering calls, scheduling, verifying insurnace, etc). 

Looking if anyone has any tips and tricks for making it a smooth process or anything you used to help as this will be a remote position. 

I will still be taking over some of the admin duties part of the day and then our employee we are hiring will be working the later half of each day.

Not exactly sure what I‚Äôm looking for, but just want to see how others handle this as I‚Äôm putting together some training resources and envisioning how everything will work between sharing duties split between the hours of the day. 

TIA! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

comments.text:
Hi! I manage our admin Team. If this will be remote position, you'll need to set the tone for productivity and priorities from day 1. I also recommend them coming in a day or couple of shifts during the week if possible.

The greatest impact that one can have is keeping your schedule full.. time is of the essence. I call it the window of opportunity. If a patient no shows, cancels, or says they'll have to call back to schedule. They go on a call list.. calls need to be made the next day, then the very next day. If we wait until a week after their missed appointment, then the likelihood of them getting back on the schedule drops by 70%.

Referrals called same day, then the next day. Same window of opportunity applies.

These call back and referral lists should be on a spreadsheet shared via secured server so that you can see real time updates. Calls should be made at the best times. Before 9AM and after 5PM. Why? That is when people answer because that is when they are off from work.

Authorizations should be kept on a log as well with approval/denial status and visits/date range approved.

Schedule a weeks worth of appointments at a time.

Send eval/progress note updates to referring providers weekly to keep them informed and your business front and center (out of sight out of mind).

Give little bonuses/incentives for clinic growth. "If we increase by __% of visits, or if we average ___ visits for the month, then we'll give___" or "If you schedule __% of referrals that came in you get___"

Lastly, invest in remote work tools:

Ring Central so they can send and recieve faxes via email.

VOIP phone service to make and take calls from a number linked to your business. Look for an option that will provide call logs and volume so you can see how much or how little they have on their plate.

I always look for people with previous Medical office experience, sales is a plus. Must have excel, outlook, MS office experience.

Congratulations on your growth! üôå

Hey Amanda congrats on the growth. We employ a ton of admins for practices across the country. 

Big keys. Make sure you define success. What metrics/KPIs drive this position and how will you measure success. 

Make sure you have all of your log ins and scripts/SOPs in one location so that it is very easy for the admin to access. 

I find that measuring hours can be very difficult for a virtual admin so often times paying then a flat rate for a set of hours or tasks often work at the best.

post_text:
I‚Äôm sponsoring a local running event in a few weeks and I‚Äòll be able to set up a booth to market my services (my business is specifically marketed toward runners). 

For those who have done this before, what were your most effective strategies to convert on the leads you got? 
I‚Äôve seen some posts mentioning that freebie items like pens, magnets end up being a waste of money, so I‚Äôd like to avoid any rookie mistakes if I can. 

Any ideas appreciated, thanks!

comments.text: As a runner I agree to not a bunch of freebies. The local PT practice in my area sets up a mini recovery tent with a table for some stretching then a chair with compression boots and some self use foam rollers and thera guns and yoga mats on the ground. Attracting people with therapy gadgets that are reusable and require people to stick around 5-10 minutes creating conversation and not just passing by grabbing something free off a table.

Agree with above. What would you want after a race that‚Äôs not offered? 5 min stretches, theraguns, rollers, etc. things runners might use but don‚Äôt bring with them to a race. Collect emails definitely, but also ensure their contact info won‚Äôt be shared. Maybe offer a handout (given after engagement) with simple recovery tidbits. You want to make sure you understand their needs so they come to you for answers

We have a new PT starting in august. 2nd week of august.

We have new referrals scheduled out till august. And I have a cancellation list of about 10-12 patients a week right now. Getting a little overwhelmed as I don‚Äôt know what to say to patients when I‚Äôm not able to give many even 2 visits a week.

For some new eval‚Äôs I have coming up. Would it be okay to transition them to our new PT‚Äôs schedule? Maybe saying something how they will be able to get in more for visits with the new PT. But then again, I don‚Äôt want them to think ‚Äúwhy does the new PT not have a full schedule?‚Äù Maybe I‚Äôm overthinking. 

Also, was wondering when the front desk assistant calls the new referrals to schedule for august. What‚Äôs the best way to say that they will be with our new PT? A lot of people know me/my name in town. But I don‚Äôt want them to think that only I‚Äôm the ‚Äúgo-to person to see‚Äù

I pretty much plan on giving most/all new referrals to our new PT.

Any advice would be greatly appreciated?

comments.text:
If u say we have a great PT starting with us in August, I think it should be self explanatory why they don‚Äôt have a full schedule. I wouldn‚Äôt say she is ‚Äúnew‚Äù because people automatically think that they are new grads.
You can also say we work very closely together and always communicate about what is going on with our patients so I will be aware of anything that needs to be addressed. -something along those lines if needed.
I would just say, we are scheduling you with XYZ therapist and leave it at that. If you make a big deal out of it, patients are more likely to question it

post_text: Hi guys! For those of you with a mobile practice, how do you schedule and manage drive times between appts?

comments.text:
I serve a relatively small area with no more than 10-12 miles between patients. Schedule each patient to allow for 15 min travel time and that it‚Äôs. Pretty easy.

Biggest improvement in my efficiency was as I got busier I just gave patients scheduling options that are ideal for me instead of saying  all my availability and letting them pick.

‚ÄúI can put you on for Tuesday at 10:30‚Äù vs ‚ÄúIm available Tuesday morning, Wednesday afternoon, what works best for you‚Äù

Still new so just let the patients know my days in their particular area. I‚Äôm a mix of small town and rural country so I have my city days and my rural days.

I try really hard to keep rural days to 2 per week. Days in city allow for more visits per day and make up some of the lost visits on rural days.

So I have a few days where my space is underutilized in the evenings. I had a PTA come and ask if she could rent it to do this specialized stretching thing she does on the side of working for a corporate company to make more money. She charges her pts $100/hr and wants to give me 20% of each patient she sees. She will be there after hours or on days only when  I‚Äôm not in. Note she will be using her own table and equipment etc.

comments.text: Sounds like a good deal. Maybe could move to an where she leases once she get a good amount. post_text:
Started writing my book!!! So exciting. See below for my intro 
üëáüèº
The title is ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Buy the Minivan‚Äù

comments.text:
As a single mom of two daughters, I knew I had to work hard to make ends meet. But at the same time, I didn't want to miss out on the important moments in my daughters' lives. I wanted to be there for every sporting event, every school play, and every milestone. I wanted to be the kind of mom who could drop off and pick up her kids from school every day.

 

So, when my oldest daughter, just shy of nine years old at the time, suggested that I start my own healthcare business, I was skeptical at first. How could I possibly juggle the demands of running a business with the demands of being a mom? But the more I thought about it, the more I realized that entrepreneurship might actually be the key to achieving my goals.

 

With my daughters by my side, I embarked on a journey that was both challenging and rewarding. I learned how to balance the demands of work and family, and I discovered that with hard work and determination, anything is possible. I was able to attend all my daughters' events, drop them off and pick them up from school every day, and still build a successful healthcare business.

 

This book is my story of being a single mom and entrepreneur. It's about the challenges I faced, the lessons I learned, and the joys of being able to create a life that worked for me and my family. It's about the importance of prioritizing what truly matters and finding a way to make it work.

 

If you're a single mom who is struggling to balance work and family, or if you're an aspiring entrepreneur who wants to learn from someone who has been there, then this book is for you. It's a story of hope, inspiration, and possibility. So, join me on this journey, and let's discover together what it means to create a life that truly works for us and our families.

Nice intro
Very inspiring

post_text:
Trying to find a different way to say that we are busy to patients and we are getting so many new patients that we can‚Äôt get them in soon. Having to schedule new patients 2-3 weeks out. 

Like ‚Äúwe won‚Äôt have an opening until mid-may but I can put you on our cancellation list for an earlier opening. We do apologize but our patient volume is high‚Äù

Or what‚Äôs a better/more professional way to say it?

I‚Äôm so grateful of how busy I am but I don‚Äôt want it to negatively impact my practice because patients can‚Äôt get in. I am also looking to hire asap so that will help.

comments.text: The best way to say it without saying it is to raise prices.

A lot of times this is only viewed negatively from our lens.

Think of all the times you‚Äôve heard a patient say ‚Äúdr. Xyz is so good I couldn‚Äôt get an appointment until July‚Äù. Popular restaurants sometimes require reso weeks in advance.

Being on a waitlist or scheduling out can create demand and a sense of scarcity in the eyes of consumers. Give yourself a break (and a pat on the back), hire when you can, and preserve your boundaries and time. Very rarely is PT an emergency scenario that can‚Äôt wait a few weeks.

full_thread_text:

I‚Äôm so grateful of how busy I am but I don‚Äôt want it to negatively impact my practice because patients can‚Äôt get in. I am also looking to hire asap so that will help.

COMMENT 1: The best way to say it without saying it is to raise prices.

COMMENT 2: A lot of times this is only viewed negatively from our lens.

Think of all the times you‚Äôve heard a patient say ‚Äúdr. Xyz is so good I couldn‚Äôt get an appointment until July‚Äù. Popular restaurants sometimes require reso weeks in advance.

Being on a waitlist or scheduling out can create demand and a sense of scarcity in the eyes of consumers. Give yourself a break (and a pat on the back), hire when you can, and preserve your boundaries and time. Very rarely is PT an emergency scenario that can‚Äôt wait a few weeks.

post_text:
Happy Sunday y‚Äôall! Trying to find some thing like an electronic whiteboard or a notebook. I have an iPad and I‚Äôm trying to find an app to use and looking for recommendations. I like writing things out and being able to look back at them, kind of like journaling, or jotting down ideas. Anyone have an app that they like for that?

Ôøº

comments.text: I just got a Rocketbook and I love it!

Notability is a good iPad app that works like a notebook, journal, planner, etc. you can set it up however you like. 

Rocketbooks are also great if you wanted a physical notebook, because you write whatever you want then scan in their app and it turns your physical writing into a digital copy to be emailed, stored in google docs, Dropbox etc. 

I use both for different purposes and really enjoy them.

post_text:
Long rant. Feeling a bit down. Love working for ourselves rather than someone else. But I am in a mental rut. Like big time. There is a never ending list of things to do/get caught up on and I feel I'm just tredding water (i want to be in a place where i have maybe 1 or 2 PTs at most working with us and not just status quo). Once we get systems in place and all the dust settles from switching documentation systems from January, I hope things improve.

But what do you all do to stay focused and motivated?! All the small random tasks that keep holding us back are just so daunting. 

The funny thing is when we worked for someone else, we basically did EVERYTHING we currently do.....so I thought it would be a quick transition. But it's such a struggle to get ahold of our new setup with no true systems in place. I literally cannot focus on getting my notes done because all I can think of is the back end of things with all the tasks that need to get done. 

Sorry for the long post....but gah! We are coming up on our 3rd anniversary in September and truly thought we would be in a better spot in general (not necessarily financially) just with workflow and growth

comments.text: Well üòÇüòÇ as long as your business partner doesn‚Äôt steal the bank and run off ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm betting you got this.

Expectations will get you every time‚Ä¶stay in the day and stay in the moment..do your very best with each thing you do

Got good advice once in 1971‚Ä¶keep your brain where your feet are and to thine own self be true

And after 53+ years as a PT I still use it every day

post_text:
Looking for perspectives on discovery calls and coaching/wellness. I use Jane for EMR. I have scheduled discovery/complimentary consultation calls (virtual) through Jane, with some individuals ultimately not being appropriate for and/or choosing not to move forward with care. I don't want to mess up my metrics on Jane when I go to look quarterly/at the end of the year as I can't just delete these clients out of the system afterwards.

Does anyone schedule their discovery calls and wellness/coaching clients through a system outside of their standard EMR? I have heard of Practicebetter, IntakeQ, Calendly, etc. I would love to keep it all in one place, but not sure if there is a better way to do things.

TIA!

post_text: I need some guidance. We have a patient (workers comp case) that just started. He has had an eval and one treatment. He has already made us extremely uncomfortable and we are fearful of being caught in litigation because of him. He continues to cancel his appointments but accuses us of not wanting to see him. He is also very accusatory of his surgeon. What steps do we need to take to protect ourselves? Can we choose to no longer accept him as a patient? What constitutes patient abondonment? We are documenting conversations so that we have it in file.

comments.text: Do you have a policy on cancellations? I've dc'd patients for multiple late cancels before.

Also, keep in mind Workmen‚Äôs Comp patients are not automatically ‚Äúpriority cases‚Äù. It sounds like ‚Ä¶maybe I‚Äôm just reading between the lines‚Ä¶ but if you don‚Äôt have their ideal appointment spot for them, then they are accusing you of not wanting to see them but remember that these patients are not priority patients. meaning they don‚Äôt take priority over other patients that are already on your schedule, so you have no obligation to see them at their ‚Äúon demand‚Äù or requested time and the best you can do is work with what you have available. Then potentially DC if the schedules are not lining up.

post_text: Hey everyone! Looking to get feedback on your follow up protocols when someone has expressed interest in booking but then doesn't get back to you. Also, how and how often you follow up after the initial visit when they don't want to book another appointment right then and there, but say they will go on the website to book. Thanks!

comments.text: I always follow the initial evaluation with a detailed email telling them what we discussed and their exercises. At the end of the email, I remind them I typically see patients less often than a traditional therapist and ask them to reach out with their needs. After a week (regardless if they scheduled another appointment) I do a quick follow up email to make sure exercises are going well. After that, I tend to let them go as they probably wouldn‚Äôt be a good fit for me. They tend to schedule another appointment between those 2 emails thoughüòä Hope this helps!
Bumping because I need help, please!

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey everyone! Looking to get feedback on your follow up protocols when someone has expressed interest in booking but then doesn't get back to you. Also, how and how often you follow up after the initial visit when they don't want to book another appointment right then and there, but say they will go on the website to book. Thanks!

COMMENT 1: I always follow the initial evaluation with a detailed email telling them what we discussed and their exercises. At the end of the email, I remind them I typically see patients less often than a traditional therapist and ask them to reach out with their needs. After a week (regardless if they scheduled another appointment) I do a quick follow up email to make sure exercises are going well. After that, I tend to let them go as they probably wouldn‚Äôt be a good fit for me. They tend to schedule another appointment between those 2 emails thoughüòä Hope this helps!

COMMENT 2: Bumping because I need help, please!

post_text: Hi- I live in a big city where parking is a headache and I don‚Äôt want to be lugging a portable table around to do mobile sessions. comments.text:
Do you NEED a table? I do mobile and honestly feel like as someone who is not a heavy manual therapist that I get by fine without.

I also started in City and honestly could bike between some appointments!
I've been doing mobile for over 2 years and we are busier than ever and no one that works here has ever brought a table.  I'm in Chicago for reference.

post_text: Hey everyone! I know similar questions have been asked, but I just started my cash based practice with my first week of clients last week. I had a woman reach out to me from social media who wants to work with me for coaching purposes. She's based in the UK. Legally, this is okay to do as long as consent and intake forms are completed addressing that I am NOT her physical therapist nor treating under my DPT license?

comments.text:
AI answered this.

Yes, you can provide coaching services to clients located in the UK as long as you have the appropriate consent and intake forms in place. You should also make sure that you are aware of any local laws and regulations that may apply to your practice. Additionally, it is important to make sure that you clearly communicate to your client that you are not providing physical therapy services and that you are not licensed to do so.

post_text: Anyone have a written no-show/cancellation policy they would like the share? I have tried not to, but now I‚Äôm putting off patients for people who don‚Äôt come. Any tips on how to implement would also be welcomed. Thank you in advance.

comments.text: I have a cancellation policy acknowledgment form they sign with their intake paperwork. I started with a 50% cancellation fee when I started my business 4 yrs ago. I quickly updated it to 24 hr within a few months. Decide what you can cover in the occurrence of a cancellation and include it in your intake paperwork. I think this can vary greatly on your area, resources of your clientele, and your own business plan. I adapted mine from what I googled online and what I receive from my MDs and allied Med when I seek services in my area.
There may be one in the ‚Äúfiles‚Äù section of this page.

I think this can vary greatly on your area, resources of your clientele, and your own business plan. post_text:
Hello! I got my LLC and liability insurance!! Whoo hoo! 
I am a mobile PT So what would be my next immediate step to be able to see patients? Do I need my NPI? Or can I just start! 

How do you handle the payment if you don‚Äôt have a system in place yet? 

What forms are must haves? (I took the Bootcamp so there are forms somewhere correct?) 
Do I have to have an Rx from a doctor if I see PTs in MO? 
Sorry for all the questions! Just excited and nervous!

comments.text:
Congrats! 

Get your NPI and get an EIN (tax number). I take cash and checks currently, I‚Äôm too small to pay credit card fees right now. Need consent and intake forms. Consent form you need a HIPAA or privacy policy part, consent to treatment part, financial agreement part as basic info. I think those are the most important. Highly highly advise you read your state practice act, I‚Äôm in Texas so I can‚Äôt help you there! Technically you can see people as long as you have your license up to date as well! Figure out if you want an EMR and/or how you‚Äôre going to document, get a business checking/savings and credit card set up for the LLC. Read up on Medicare participating or non participating enrollments on the page here to see if you want to go through that process as well.

Ideally, I want a system that will allow me to request an in-person signature by handing them my tablet or smart phone, have them sign it, and have the system store it in each patient‚Äôs individually created folder, that way all of each patient‚Äôs signatures are stored and organized in one place and easily accessible rather than having random signatures over all patients all over the place in a master folder. All insight and advice would be highly appreciated. Thank you.

COMMENT 1: In Jane you can collect signatures for each visit and each signature would be tied that specific treatment note.

COMMENT 2: I do exactly that. I have them sign my tablet by hand. I use Adobe. Once they sign then I save their forms to their personal folder.

post_text:
Is the solo practice era coming to an end?
There are fear that the solo practitioner will be a rare, or thing of the past. True as that my seem; especially to those whose income and business model is married to third-party payers, there is also a growing part of healthcare clinicians may be ignoring. It is the cash-paying patient. OK, before you dismiss me, hear me out! Most insured Americans have high deductibles, making them cash patients up to 6 or 12k (whatever their deductible is). In addition, a growing part of the population is without insurance. Combined, these two groups make up 51% of Americans. So, why are we bothering to fight with insurance companies when most patients cannot use it even when they have it? Because we have always looked to insurance companies to tell us what we are worth.
Here is the problem with processing insurance for patients with high deductibles. The overhead goes up by multiples whenever insurance companies have to put their blessing on your claim. Insurance is essential; however, it is now only for catastrophic events. Recurring healthcare should be cash-based.
That brings us to the how? How do you start a cash practice? Several platforms on the market can help. Because I am a clinician and a software engineer, I created a marketplace that allows all the providers and me on the platform to state what they charge and the insurances they accept. In turn, I drive patients to the platform, and they get to choose a provider based on price, insurance accepted, distance from the provider, reputation rating, etc. The platform takes the provider to the discomfort of negotiating prices with patients. Furthermore, when the patients book appointments, they pay online, so I do not have to employ an army of people to collect my money. All the providers on Hutano have told me they love how the idea of a marketplace like this saves time and money.
Overhead is a real issue in healthcare. And it comes in two flavors, fixed and variable. Fixed overhead may be what it is. Meaning there is little you can do about it. Variable overhead, on the other hand, you can manage with technology.
I hear healthcare is complicated more often than I can count. But is it that different from other industries? Actually, not really! Consider this; there are five essential steps to accessing and providing primary healthcare. Finding a healthcare provider, booking an appointment, completing paperwork, receiving care, and follow-up care. If we figure out how to create technology that addresses the inefficiencies in each step, we will have fixed healthcare - at least primary care.
Traditionally, healthcare tends to mesh many technologies together and hope everything will work out. Inevitably we solve upstream problems without applying any thought to the downstream issues.
Let me give an example. Suppose you use  Zoc Doc to automate and manage scheduling. Great! Your patients find you and book appointments efficiently. However, your waiting room is still packed with patients filling out paperwork. And yes! your patients still wait 45 minutes plus to receive care. At the end of the day, you are overwhelmed despite the efficient scheduling. So what is the solution?
Software should make our lives more efficient. Unfortunately, no software on the market addresses the inefficiencies in each of the five steps. Practice management software should make finding providers and booking appointments as simple as Zoc Doc. Furthermore, patients should be able to fill out the intake, attach pertinent medical documents like imaging and lab reports, then pay for medical services online. By the time a patient walks into the clinic, the provider should be armed with all they need to diagnose and treat. But why stop there? The information a patient just entered into their intake could transfer automatically into the HPI portion of the encounter note. That way, by the time a provider starts writing a note, the patient has filled out the chief complaint, medical and social histories, medication list, preferred pharmacy, and even their vitals if that is something they can do at home. So the clinician's time can be more effectively spent interpreting the objective measures in your tests and measures, assigning a diagnosis and treatment plan. It would be great if follow-up appointments were set up in the EMR and sent directly to the patient's phone. Lastly, it would be great for any outside referrals to be managed directly in the EMR, sending referrals directly to other clinicians with access to treatment notes upon acceptance or referral.
My point is that technology saves time and money because; and clinicians will not need to employ people to schedule and manage appointments. Instead, like an airline, patients can book and manage their appointments.
I created a platform three years ago that does what I just shared with you. Twelve other providers and I are on the Hutano platform, and the results have been encouraging. And, as a solo, cash-based practitioner, my time is no longer bogged down with administrative tasks. So, please visit us at Hutano.com to set up your free account, and let me know how I can help your practice be more efficient.
As a software engineer and clinician, I consult with other clinicians. Please let me know if I can be a resource for your practice. Ephraim Makuve, PT, DPT, MBA HA. www.hutano.com | also available on the Appstore and Google Play Store

post_text:
Need some advice. I‚Äôm starting up my mobile cash-pay practice this week. I had four clients scheduled to eval on Friday. One of them had contacted me by phone several weeks ago to get on the schedule, and I had asked her if she had checked out the website for information, and she said she did and agreed to schedule. I didn‚Äôt specifically mention the cash-pay piece because it‚Äôs on the website, so I didn‚Äôt want to make a big deal out of it, assuming she had seen that part. Fast forward to this week. She completed the intake paperwork, and one of the consents that she had to agree to was the payment policy which SPECIFICALLY states it is cash pay and that I do not bill insurance. Today I had an email from her asking where she can upload her insurance information on the portal. ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I responded that my practice is cash pay and that I don‚Äôt submit anything to her insurance but that I can provide a superbill for her to apply for out of network benefits. She responded and said she had misunderstood and that she wanted to use a practice that will take her insurance. I emailed her back some information and explanation, but I understand her decision.

So all that to say, do any of you have kind of a script in your head to have that conversation with patients when they want to schedule with you? I shouldn‚Äôt just assume that they know it is cash-pay, and I want to handle it tactfully.

comments.text: I always do an intake call, and always say ‚Äújust so you know, we don‚Äôt take insurance. But many of my clients submit claims on their own for out of network reimbursement. If that‚Äôs something you‚Äôd like to do, I‚Äôm happy to provide you with the paperwork after each session.‚Äù Then I tell them my prices.

I‚Äôve found it‚Äôs easier to assume they missed something critical even if they have looked me up. I also schedule an initial call with every new patient to gather basic info and enter them into my system, during this call i have a written template I pull out, which prompts me to ask for all the proper details and discuss all topics I need to ensure folks understand, so i know they‚Äôre cool with everything before I even do the work of sending a welcome email and intake paperwork. 

I collect the usual name DOB address, contact info etc. Topics I go over include my pricing and out of network status, pet policy, and at one time my mask policy since I live in the south and using masks were a dealbreaker for some patients. I usually ask about entrances/ stairs so I know what to expect.

Nothing annoyed me more than wasting a bunch of time getting everything set up, just to have them cancel last minute over something I could have spent three seconds pointing out in the intake call to double check, so I set it up this way and I highly recommend!

post_text: Hey all. Any recommendations on Jane App vs. PT Everywhere? Hoping to start taking clients for my cash-based PT biz in Feb and looking to select an EMR that streamlines everything (scheduling, documentation, HEP, billing/invoice/superbills, etc.)!

comments.text: I just finished setting up all my stuff with Jane. I did demos with both and chose Jane partly due to aesthetics but also price. I did set up a separate fax number through SRFax for like $111 for the year, though I haven‚Äôt had to use it yet. Jane connects to physitrack for HEP‚Äôs, though I‚Äôm probably going to have to upload my own exercises as I haven‚Äôt found what I want for my pregnant and postpartum clients on there yet. I found it very easy to follow the virtual guidance for setting up staff (I‚Äôm the only clinician), scheduling, visit types with rates (I‚Äôm also using Jane payments through Stripe), creating templates, and creating intake forms with consents. It took me a few days, maybe a week, to get things the way I want it, but coming from HCHB in home health, I am SO excited to use a more streamlined EMR that isn‚Äôt just checking off a bunch of insurance-mandated requirements that do not pertain to my patient or their treatment!

I‚Äôve used both and I‚Äôm obsessed with Jane now. The only downside is that Jane doesn‚Äôt hav e-fax built in (yet).

They also provide a ‚Äúhelper rate‚Äù that saves you $25/month on whichever plan you go with. With wanting to do superbills I‚Äôd go with the insurance place. 

The aesthetic, patient satisfaction, and customer service is seriously unparalleled!

post_text: Mobile Neuro Business. I am also wanting to add on OT and SLP later this year or next year. Medicare/Cash. Which EMR system would you recommend and why? Preferrably something with billing unless you think that with Medicare only its not too terrible to do it myself.

comments.text: I don‚Äôt want to vote in the poll as I don‚Äôt know about any of the systems except Jane, and I don‚Äôt use it for billing since I‚Äôm cash-based. But I‚Äôll just throw in my opinion that Jane is easy to use for me (I‚Äôm just one person who is not particularly tech-savvy, and I got it all set up and ready to go by myself, with assistance from a responsive customer service and set-up guides). Ask me in two weeks when I actually start seeing patients with it lol. (I‚Äôve made a demo patient and done just about everything I can think of that I would need to in a patient‚Äôs chart, including accepting payment, and it was so easy. On a side note, my sister houses HelloNote and likes it too. She also does Medicare billing with it.)

I've used WebPT with TheraBill, HelloNote and Prompt.  Prompt hands down has been the best.  It is super user friendly, keeps me very organized, easy to find things, alerts if the patient POC is under or over however many visits for any weeks, I like their documentation as it flows easier than HelloNote.  HelloNote was excellent for more of a minimalistic approach, but they are adding more features and I know a lot of therapists who use it!  Prompt also integrates with srfax, PTWired, and I just liked the features.  The features save me an immense amount of time to find admin or billing items and I can quickly address.  The support with HelloNote was great and very timely.  I also really love Prompt's support them.  Plus, they have a Chick-fil-a feel with their desire and happiness to help.  Their support is a team of clinicians and billers so they can answer a lot more questions since they understand what the question is.  I'm unsure of others that do that.  Hope that helps!

In the end, do what works best for your practice!  I wear a lot of hats in my business because I want to, so I wanted more robust, save time, efficiency, etc.

Oh...VERY important to add, make sure to do a demo with the ones you want to look at, and make sure they are confident in their answers about dealing with insurance or Medicare.  (Example: how does the EMR keep up with the threshold, POC ending, fax status or log if ever audited, etc)  I've heard wonderful things with Jane, and I'm not sure if they've added much on the insurance side yet that can help alert you with those.  Maybe someone else can have input!
